description: The Certified Cloud Security Professional (CCSP) is a credential that is going to be relevant especially for people who want to focus on the knowledge areas of architectural concepts and design requirements, cloud data security, cloud platform and infrastructure security, cloud application security, and compliance concerns in a traditional standard enterprise environment. As powerful as cloud computing is for the organization, understanding its information security risks and mitigation strategies are critical. Legacy approaches are inadequate, and organizations need competent, experienced professionals equipped with the right cloud security knowledge and skills to be successful. The CCSP certification is for IT professionals with a minimum of five years of cumulative IT experience with backgrounds and exposure to cloud related services.
name: Certified Cloud Security Professional (UPDATED 2016)
subtitle: CCSP

29

30
00:01:19.535 --> 00:01:21.750
Let's start at the bottom of the stack,
work our way up.

31
00:01:21.750 --> 00:01:24.880
This is remember where we provision

32
00:01:24.880 --> 00:01:28.380

say, hey, I want five hosts,

33
00:01:28.380 --> 00:01:30.750

this much storage.

34

I want this much CPU.

35

I want this much network bandwidth.

36

37
00:01:37.920 --> 00:01:41.070
Really the key components and
characteristics here are scalability,

38
00:01:41.070 --> 00:01:44.430
converged networks and
IT capacity in terms of pooling, so

39
00:01:44.430 --> 00:01:48.440
we can rely on that bandwidth, rely on
that storage infrastructure, excuse me.

40
00:01:48.440 --> 00:01:52.470
And rely on those performance
enhancement capabilities of CPUs and

41
00:01:52.470 --> 00:01:53.870
RAM being allocated up.

42

Self service and or on demand capacity and
high reliability and

43

resilience are typically

44
00:01:59.490 --> 00:02:03.330
Key benefits traditionally, usage is
metered and priced on the basis of some

45
00:02:03.330 --> 00:02:06.830
sort of consumption so I use so
many processor cycles.

46
00:02:06.830 --> 00:02:11.660
I use so many units of storage, whatever
it may be and I'm paying for that as I go.

47
00:02:11.660 --> 00:02:15.026
So I really am in charge of my world
in a sense that I can decide what I

48
00:02:15.026 --> 00:02:17.906
wanna provision and
what I ultimately want to not own but

49
00:02:17.906 --> 00:02:21.851
essentially rent because remember
we're not owning the infrastructure.

50
00:02:21.851 --> 00:02:24.636
We are, and this is a really
important point for Cloud services.

51
00:02:24.636 --> 00:02:28.174
We are taking what would
traditionally be a cap ex,

52
00:02:28.174 --> 00:02:31.386
a capital expenditure
expense where we buy and

53
00:02:31.386 --> 00:02:36.425
invest in infrastructure over a three or
five year depreciation cycle.

54
00:02:36.425 --> 00:02:38.548
And we're shifting that to an op ex,

55
00:02:38.548 --> 00:02:41.902
an operational expense on
the financial spreadsheet, or

56
00:02:41.902 --> 00:02:46.292
on essentially the balance score card
of the finances of the organization.

57
00:02:46.292 --> 00:02:50.483
And so we see a shift from cap ex to op ex
where we now have a recurring monthly fee

58
00:02:50.483 --> 00:02:54.289
more or less within a certain parameter or
certain spread if you will,

59
00:02:54.289 --> 00:02:59.001
which we know we're always spending $100
a month on average if that's what we have

60
00:02:59.001 --> 00:03:02.390
bargained for and what we've budgeted for.

61
00:03:02.390 --> 00:03:04.250
And IaaS helps us to figure that out.

62
00:03:04.250 --> 00:03:07.410
All three models do, by the way, but
they do from different perspectives.

63
00:03:07.410 --> 00:03:10.520
So metered usage,
metered consumption, scale up and

64
00:03:10.520 --> 00:03:15.215
scale down on demand, reduce costs of
ownership, this cap ex, op ex switch and

65
00:03:15.215 --> 00:03:17.935
reduced energy and cooling costs,
this is also pretty important.

66
00:03:17.935 --> 00:03:21.865
We're handing off the infrastructure
burden, reliability and

67
00:03:21.865 --> 00:03:25.895
the ownership of that to a provider that's
essentially gonna manage that on our

68
00:03:25.895 --> 00:03:30.000
behalf and factor in all those
costs to our monthly recurring fee.

69
00:03:30.000 --> 00:03:31.970
You know we as customers
don't often think about that.

70
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:32.940
So for instance,

71

72

73
00:03:36.610 --> 00:03:37.784
>> I do.
>> Any of those, all those, right.

74

75
00:03:41.572 --> 00:03:46.140
You use your cell phone with Verizon,
AT&T, Sprint.

76
00:03:46.140 --> 00:03:47.170
Who you going with, T Mobile?

77
00:03:47.170 --> 00:03:49.160
>> I think we're with AT&T here.

78
00:03:49.160 --> 00:03:52.170
>> Okay, so AT&T right, and Verizon.

79
00:03:52.170 --> 00:03:54.580
And you know my story about my Blackberry.

80
00:03:54.580 --> 00:03:56.030
Me and John Chen the CEO.

81

Two people in the world

82
00:03:58.080 --> 00:03:59.380
But, I'm on Verizon.

84

85

I'm gonna bill you know x number

the rest essentially is mine

And as a result I know every

88

it touches every aspect of what we do.

92
00:04:24.110 --> 00:04:26.430
Cell phones today It's cable today.

93
00:04:26.430 --> 00:04:28.040
It's anything you can think of, right?

94
00:04:28.040 --> 00:04:31.650
I mean you know, you drive so far, you
pay so much in gas, gas costs x number of

95
00:04:31.650 --> 00:04:34.650
dollars a gallon, you're essentially
consuming, you know what it takes.

96
00:04:34.650 --> 00:04:39.545
So, this benefit is essentially gonna
be the idea of managing our expense.

97
00:04:39.545 --> 00:04:42.425
And managing our expense from
an IaaS perspective is really,

98
00:04:42.425 --> 00:04:44.275
really important for us to think about.

99
00:04:44.275 --> 00:04:45.575
What about platform as a service?

100
00:04:45.575 --> 00:04:46.315
What about PaaS?

101
00:04:46.315 --> 00:04:49.375
Moving up, we're now getting the IaaS,
the infrastructure,

102
00:04:49.375 --> 00:04:52.215
along with the operating environment,
the operating system.

103
00:04:52.215 --> 00:04:55.955
So the ability to have the cloud
service provider provision out for

104
00:04:55.955 --> 00:04:59.475
us the infrastructure and
do the build on the initial configuration.

105
00:04:59.475 --> 00:05:03.300
So customers rent hardware, the OS,
the storage, the networking, all that.

106
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:05.200
And we then are able to go ahead and

107
00:05:05.200 --> 00:05:07.870
virtualize on top of that,
door app dev work.

108
00:05:07.870 --> 00:05:11.740
We often associate PaaS with app dev,
because we think of it as being the app

109
00:05:11.740 --> 00:05:14.210
dev platform that we rent and
essentially use.

110
00:05:14.210 --> 00:05:18.058
So supporting multiple languages and
frameworks is a key, capability and

111
00:05:18.058 --> 00:05:21.810
characteristic of PaaS,
multiple host environments can be created,

112
00:05:21.810 --> 00:05:26.430
very flexible, we can auto scale, and
we allow the ability to have choice and

113
00:05:26.430 --> 00:05:29.100
therefore attempt to reduce
what's called vendor lock in,

114
00:05:29.100 --> 00:05:31.950
where we're stuck with one vendor and
one capability.

115
00:05:31.950 --> 00:05:36.430
If you want to run both Microsoft and
Linux Unix based infrastructure in your

116
00:05:36.430 --> 00:05:40.520
enterprise today, in the old-school model
of doing things where you own physical

117
00:05:40.520 --> 00:05:44.190
infrastructure, you had to buy and
provision all that infrastructure, and

118
00:05:44.190 --> 00:05:46.520
you had to duplicate your
servers essentially to run both.

119
00:05:46.520 --> 00:05:49.370
You know, for
instance traditionally in web hosting,

120
00:05:49.370 --> 00:05:52.830
Linux really plays a very big part
in that and has for many many years.

121
00:05:52.830 --> 00:05:56.550
That's where we see the majority of web
hosting being done whereas in directory

122
00:05:56.550 --> 00:06:01.540
services and in messaging platforms,
enterprise content management,

123
00:06:01.540 --> 00:06:05.570
file and print that's usually the purview
of Microsoft more often than not.

124
00:06:05.570 --> 00:06:07.298
Not exclusively but more often than not,

125
00:06:07.298 --> 00:06:11.100
very heavily weighted in the enterprise
in favor of Microsoft in those areas.

126
00:06:11.100 --> 00:06:15.940
So as a result, you may buy both and
provision both and it's very expensive.

127
00:06:15.940 --> 00:06:18.560
With PaaS you just rent
that infrastructure and

128
00:06:18.560 --> 00:06:21.190
say I want 20 web servers,
I want them to run Linux.

129
00:06:21.190 --> 00:06:25.020
No problem, we provision out two or three
hosts, we give you the capability to run

130
00:06:25.020 --> 00:06:29.970
five or six VMs, guest operating systems
per host and you provision them out.

131
00:06:29.970 --> 00:06:33.190
And you got your 20 web servers, and
you're getting them for a lot less than if

132
00:06:33.190 --> 00:06:36.890
you had to go buy them for
three to five years and own them yourself.

133
00:06:36.890 --> 00:06:39.740
And then having to have them set them up,
having to license them,

134
00:06:39.740 --> 00:06:40.670
having to maintain them and

135
00:06:40.670 --> 00:06:44.910
update them over time is now being
transferred to the cloud service provider.

136
00:06:44.910 --> 00:06:47.999
And for that monthly fee, they
essentially are taking on those risks and

137
00:06:47.999 --> 00:06:49.032
those concerns for us.

138
00:06:49.032 --> 00:06:51.385
So there's a lot of value
potentially in this model.

139
00:06:51.385 --> 00:06:53.930
So a lot of capabilities,
a lot of key characteristics.

140
00:06:53.930 --> 00:06:56.820
So the operating system is
managed by the provider.

141
00:06:56.820 --> 00:06:58.050
Meaning they do patch management,

142
00:06:58.050 --> 00:07:00.810
they do upgrades to
the underlying core functionality.

143
00:07:00.810 --> 00:07:02.050
Wouldn't it be interesting.

144
00:07:02.050 --> 00:07:03.600
And again,
there's liability with everything.

145
00:07:03.600 --> 00:07:05.340
So take this with a grain of salt.

146
00:07:05.340 --> 00:07:08.830
But isn't it interesting in this kind of
a model where we can decide that we want

147
00:07:08.830 --> 00:07:13.410
to go from Server 12 to 12 R2 or
12 R2 to 16 or

148
00:07:13.410 --> 00:07:18.660
Linux Redhat version 5 to version 7
simply by selecting a premade template or

149
00:07:18.660 --> 00:07:22.550
a running instance of some VM that we
could then upgrade and that the provider's

150
00:07:22.550 --> 00:07:25.790
already taken care of the licensing,
figured out the deployment model.

151
00:07:25.790 --> 00:07:28.230
All we have to do is click
a couple of buttons in theory,

152
00:07:28.230 --> 00:07:32.310
maybe write a little script or
use a deployment automation capability.

153
00:07:32.310 --> 00:07:35.240
And 20, 30 minutes later
we've got a running instance.

154
00:07:35.240 --> 00:07:38.125
As opposed to I have to
download the operating system.

155
00:07:38.125 --> 00:07:40.280
I have to read up on how to deploy it.

156
00:07:40.280 --> 00:07:44.050
I may or may not be able to do the scaling
myself or it's very complicated.

157
00:07:44.050 --> 00:07:46.082
So you know there's a lot
of moving parts there.

158
00:07:46.082 --> 00:07:48.241
PaaS really takes all this away,
the vendor is dealing with this.

159
00:07:48.241 --> 00:07:52.242
Now the down side, the dark side is that
you may be forced to upgrade on a platform

160
00:07:52.242 --> 00:07:55.472
without necessarily having control
over when that occurs, and

161
00:07:55.472 --> 00:07:57.648
that is one of the liabilities with cloud.

162
00:07:57.648 --> 00:08:02.455
Because as we move further up the stack
from IaaS to PaaS and ultimately to SaaS,

163
00:08:02.455 --> 00:08:06.564
It is the cloud service provider
that is controlling those levers.

164
00:08:06.564 --> 00:08:10.480
When we upgrade, under what conditions and
the testing and the reliability and

165
00:08:10.480 --> 00:08:14.513
the patch management is all done by the
vendor, which means essentially I may wake

166
00:08:14.513 --> 00:08:18.650
up on Monday morning running Server 12
R2 and next Monday I may have Server 16.

167
00:08:18.650 --> 00:08:21.280
And I may or
may not have anything to say about it.

168
00:08:21.280 --> 00:08:22.780
So I do have to understand that.

169
00:08:22.780 --> 00:08:24.565
And I do have to be an educated consumer.

170
00:08:24.565 --> 00:08:27.270
We come back to this
idea of caveat emptor.

171
00:08:27.270 --> 00:08:28.780
As we talked about in the last episode.

172
00:08:28.780 --> 00:08:30.040
Right?
Buyer beware.

173
00:08:30.040 --> 00:08:33.250
It stipulates very clearly in those
hosting agreements that the vendor,

174
00:08:33.250 --> 00:08:36.260
the cloud service provider is
in control of that platform and

175
00:08:36.260 --> 00:08:38.380
you have to understand how
to play by those rules.

176
00:08:38.380 --> 00:08:42.270
Now to be fair to cloud service providers,
they do typically provide an opt-out and

177
00:08:42.270 --> 00:08:46.460
a deferment clause where you can push
off that upgrade for a period of time.

178
00:08:46.460 --> 00:08:50.130
They do work with you, but at some point,
push comes to shove and guess what,

179
00:08:50.130 --> 00:08:54.430
you're running Exchange 13 or Exchange
16 or whatever it is on the back end.

180
00:08:54.430 --> 00:08:56.292
And you're just gonna
have to make it work.

181
00:08:56.292 --> 00:08:58.650
So you have to give up
a certain level of control.

182
00:08:58.650 --> 00:09:00.820
In order to gain some
of these capabilities.

183
00:09:00.820 --> 00:09:02.410
And you want to make sure
you're aware of that.

184
00:09:02.410 --> 00:09:04.650
>> We now feel our users, right?

185
00:09:04.650 --> 00:09:06.370
They tend to complain anytime-
>> We don't care about them.

186
00:09:06.370 --> 00:09:07.440
>> We do that software update.

187
00:09:07.440 --> 00:09:09.030
Yeah. We don't care- >> Yeah,
they're a bunch of pansies.

188
00:09:09.030 --> 00:09:09.790
>> They care a lot.

189
00:09:09.790 --> 00:09:11.638
>> No, they're a bunch of pansies,
we don't care about them.

190
00:09:11.638 --> 00:09:12.785
>> [LAUGH] I agree, I'm with you.

191
00:09:12.785 --> 00:09:14.325
Let's rule IT with an iron fist.

192
00:09:14.325 --> 00:09:16.527
>> I'm a benevolent dictator
as long as you vote my way.

193
00:09:16.527 --> 00:09:17.185
>> [LAUGH]
>> If not,

194
00:09:17.185 --> 00:09:19.985
you will feel the wrath of
the undefined cloud, right.

195
00:09:19.985 --> 00:09:20.605
>> That's right.

196
00:09:20.605 --> 00:09:22.595
>> The short, but undefined cloud.

197
00:09:22.595 --> 00:09:25.025
But it is actually a really
good point all kidding aside.

198
00:09:25.025 --> 00:09:28.250
So users tend to bear the brunt of this
which is kind of the point you were

199
00:09:28.250 --> 00:09:31.380
making, which is that wake up on
Monday morning and all of a sudden,

200
00:09:31.380 --> 00:09:32.700
the backend is different.

201
00:09:32.700 --> 00:09:36.560
We may not be changing the front
end to kind of be equitable, right.

202
00:09:36.560 --> 00:09:38.310
We may not change
the front end application.

203
00:09:38.310 --> 00:09:41.790
So office may still be office they're
a team even though it's running,

204
00:09:41.790 --> 00:09:46.130
hypothetically against Exchange 16 or
SharePoint 16 or whatever.

205
00:09:46.130 --> 00:09:49.890
But over time, that office client
will then rev to version 16,

206
00:09:49.890 --> 00:09:52.070
as it's already doing on Office 365,

207
00:09:52.070 --> 00:09:55.910
and you have that capability, if you're
all in buying office on the platform.

208

661
00:32:47.165 --> 00:32:50.555

data in transit.

All three areas of the data life cycle.

We wanna think about the fact
that when data is being used,

00:33:06.201 --> 00:33:07.914

669
00:33:07.914 --> 00:33:11.028
And when it is in storage, long and

671
00:33:12.093 --> 00:33:15.880
So that way, if somebody does get access

672

673
00:33:18.790 --> 00:33:21.150
Makes it a lot more difficult for

674

So, we talked about data in transit,

675
00:33:25.500 --> 00:33:26.960
Making sure we're aware of that.

So, you have to think about that.

identity and

00:25:17.480 --> 00:25:20.180
So the reality is, these can be issues.

00:25:20.180 --> 00:25:23.560
I can easily rent space in my data
center if I find out where your hosting.

00:25:23.560 --> 00:25:24.270
That's not hard to do.

00:25:24.270 --> 00:25:26.800
And through social engineering,

00:25:26.800 --> 00:25:28.720
that may not be real hard to do at all,
quite honestly.

00:25:28.720 --> 00:25:32.910
All I have to do is attack your physical
infrastructure, meaning your building,

00:25:32.910 --> 00:25:36.810
where you are actually located, figure out
how to get a job on that cleaning crew.

00:25:36.810 --> 00:25:39.730
Get in there in there in night and start
going through people's offices looking for

00:25:39.730 --> 00:25:40.600
hosting contracts.

00:25:40.600 --> 00:25:42.770
It won't be too hard to
figure out where you host,

00:25:42.770 --> 00:25:44.310
even if they're locked
up in a file cabinet.

00:25:45.310 --> 00:25:47.460
How hard is it to wait until
somebody throws something away,

00:25:47.460 --> 00:25:49.800
and all I do is pull it out of the trash.

00:25:49.800 --> 00:25:50.850
Fins are not very hard at all.

I can probably find that information in
the IT offices, because, it's probably up

on one of your plots up on the wall,

All I gotta do is go in and
look when you're not there.

00:26:04.800 --> 00:26:07.100
And to clean an office for a couple of
nights to get inside and take pictures,

00:26:07.100 --> 00:26:09.870
when nobody is looking
I'll do that all day.

When I do pin testing, that's the kind
of stuff we do to break into systems and

00:26:13.430 --> 00:26:15.600
figure out how to socially
engineer our way in.

00:26:15.600 --> 00:26:18.500
It's not hard to do at all, and
it's done all the time in the cloud.

00:26:18.500 --> 00:26:21.860
It's just that you may not think about it
because again, it's the physical world and

00:26:21.860 --> 00:26:23.730
the physical world does
not exist in the cloud.

00:26:23.730 --> 00:26:24.760
Well, sure it does.

00:26:24.760 --> 00:26:27.590
It exists the same exact way, but
we gotta think about that right?

00:26:27.590 --> 00:26:30.590
Cloud virtual infrastructure threats,
multi-tenancy.

00:26:30.590 --> 00:26:33.530
We gotta be worried about and concerned
about the idea there's a thousand other

00:26:33.530 --> 00:26:36.560
people sharing that same conduit for
services I am.

00:26:36.560 --> 00:26:41.190
If the service provider is not spot on
with isolation, zoning and masking,

00:26:41.190 --> 00:26:43.750
the things they gotta do,
we're gonna have a problem.

00:26:43.750 --> 00:26:46.370
I'm gonna have a problem and
my data's gonna be exposed.

00:26:46.370 --> 00:26:51.700
Workload complexity, loss of control,
logical network segmentation.

00:26:51.700 --> 00:26:53.380
Lack of understanding
of physical endpoints.

00:26:53.380 --> 00:26:54.610
Single point of entry.

00:26:54.610 --> 00:26:57.370
An egress, an access to infrastructure.

00:26:57.370 --> 00:27:00.160
Any or all these things are threats
that we have to worry about in the cloud

00:27:00.160 --> 00:27:01.660
with virtualized infrastructure.

00:27:01.660 --> 00:27:02.990
This is a big deal.

00:27:02.990 --> 00:27:05.840
The platform is the service
issues that we talk about often.

00:27:05.840 --> 00:27:08.420
System or resource isolation,
again, the same idea.

00:27:08.420 --> 00:27:11.590
How do we logically and
physically isolate our environments.

00:27:11.590 --> 00:27:15.340
How do we provision user access to
the app dev environment so we can isolate

00:27:15.340 --> 00:27:19.200
instances running, virtualized instances
running within the host right?

00:27:19.200 --> 00:27:22.750
So this is also important, how do we
deal with malware back doors trojans.

00:27:22.750 --> 00:27:25.650
Remember the vendor is providing
the infrastructure and

00:27:25.650 --> 00:27:27.340
the operating system and paths.

00:27:27.340 --> 00:27:30.650
They are responsible for the OS
they're responsible for security and

00:27:30.650 --> 00:27:31.620
patch management.

00:27:31.620 --> 00:27:35.140
If they're not doing their job I could
be as tight as I want to be on my

00:27:35.140 --> 00:27:38.960
access control in the front end,
if they allow malware onto the platform

00:27:38.960 --> 00:27:41.600
I may have no control over
how to deal with that.

00:27:41.600 --> 00:27:45.170
As a matter of fact, that risk is
a risk that we have to identify in pass

00:27:45.170 --> 00:27:48.820
environment and document and
make sure we are willing to accept,

00:27:48.820 --> 00:27:51.970
as a way of doing business,
because if the vendor drops the ball,

00:27:51.970 --> 00:27:54.480
I'm gonna be on the receiving end
of that whether I wanna be or not.

00:27:54.480 --> 00:27:57.540
And I have no control over that at all,
in a past environment.

00:27:57.540 --> 00:27:58.890
So we have to think about that.

00:27:58.890 --> 00:28:03.390
Denial or distributed denial of service
can happen VM to VM against a host.

00:28:03.390 --> 00:28:06.480
And those VMs can be used to
suck resources out of a host.

00:28:06.480 --> 00:28:08.100
Or in a clustered environment,

00:28:08.100 --> 00:28:12.620
a collection of hosts that are running
jointly to provide pooled infrastructure.

00:28:12.620 --> 00:28:15.890
We could suck the life out of
an entire cluster by one VM or

00:28:15.890 --> 00:28:20.380
group of VM's being taken over
essentially zombie or botified right and

00:28:20.380 --> 00:28:23.190
then being used to execute denial or
distribute denial at the source

00:28:23.190 --> 00:28:26.320
attacks internally against the rest
of that infrastructure pool.

00:28:26.320 --> 00:28:28.790
This can happen I'm not
suggesting it does.

00:28:28.790 --> 00:28:30.330
But I'm not suggesting it doesn't.

00:28:30.330 --> 00:28:33.580
It's very clear that it could and
in certain cases it has.

00:28:33.580 --> 00:28:35.300
And we have to understand that.

00:28:35.300 --> 00:28:37.810
Past tenants should not have
shell access to the servers

00:28:37.810 --> 00:28:40.600
that they are running their instances on,
even when virtualized.

00:28:40.600 --> 00:28:44.530
Because, if we're given that then we
may be able to control that host.

00:28:44.530 --> 00:28:47.960
And that host may be used to control
multiple tenants simultaneously.

00:28:47.960 --> 00:28:49.330
And that's something to consider.

00:28:49.330 --> 00:28:53.430
Remember, the cloud provider controls
the host and the infrastructure

00:28:53.430 --> 00:28:56.210
as well as the operational
environment on the host and pass.

00:28:56.210 --> 00:28:57.780
We simply run on top of it.

00:28:57.780 --> 00:29:01.100
When I run past infrastructure, I may or
may not have dedicated hosting.

00:29:01.100 --> 00:29:04.820
I can have that option, but I have to
contractually stipulate I want that and

00:29:04.820 --> 00:29:05.880
I may not always have that.

00:29:05.880 --> 00:29:08.390
>> So, Adam,
this really comes down to the fact of

00:29:08.390 --> 00:29:11.610
what am I willing to risk
by going to the cloud?

00:29:11.610 --> 00:29:15.400
And then if I'm not willing to take those
risks then I need to keep it internal,

00:29:15.400 --> 00:29:18.720
I need to keep it in a private cloud.

00:29:18.720 --> 00:29:22.620
>> Yes, I think that's fair to say,
right, we should be aware of the fact,

00:29:22.620 --> 00:29:26.150
well with the following stipulation,
right, we talk about private cloud.

00:29:26.150 --> 00:29:29.190
We wanna make sure we talk about private
cloud on prem that we control exclusively

00:29:29.190 --> 00:29:31.860
versus private cloud that may
be outsourced to a provider.

00:29:31.860 --> 00:29:35.510
So, yes, with the caveat that not all
private clouds are equal because not all

00:29:35.510 --> 00:29:39.140
private clouds are uniquely tailored
to the needs of our environment and

00:29:39.140 --> 00:29:40.940
uniquely controlled by us.

00:29:40.940 --> 00:29:45.620
But assuming it's a private cloud on prem
with that caveat, absolutely, 100% agree.

00:29:45.620 --> 00:29:48.330
However if it's a private cloud
that we outsource centrally,

00:29:48.330 --> 00:29:50.710
right to a third party provider,
we're in the same boat.

00:29:50.710 --> 00:29:54.220
We're back to where we were, which is you
know we want to have that control but

00:29:54.220 --> 00:29:59.370
we don't really because the cloud provider
centrally is providing those elements and

00:29:59.370 --> 00:30:02.360
we may not have total understanding nor
visibility.

00:30:02.360 --> 00:30:06.990
Into critical elements, like, logging,
access control to the physical plane

00:30:06.990 --> 00:30:09.780
as supposed or to the data plane or
the management plane.

00:30:09.780 --> 00:30:12.700
These our concerns in the cloud
that we really have to think about.

00:30:12.700 --> 00:30:14.300
We have to be aware of.

00:30:14.300 --> 00:30:15.130
So, you make a valid point.

00:30:15.130 --> 00:30:18.900
We just really want to carve out and
clarify that distinction.

00:30:18.900 --> 00:30:20.760
Of private cloud being played on
both sides of the divide there.

00:30:20.760 --> 00:30:22.400
It's got to be on prem private cloud.

00:30:22.400 --> 00:30:25.110
That's really where we gain that
advantage of total management up and

00:30:25.110 --> 00:30:27.140
down the layers or across all the layers.

00:30:27.140 --> 00:30:31.950
With regards to SaaS, things like data
segregation, data access policies

00:30:31.950 --> 00:30:34.495
Web application security,
these are important security caveats and

00:30:34.495 --> 00:30:36.565
elements that we have
to think about as well.

00:30:36.565 --> 00:30:40.465
We've talked about the fact that multiple
users will store multiple tenants

00:30:40.465 --> 00:30:44.557
will store their data in application
hosted models using SaaS.

00:30:44.557 --> 00:30:48.570
Again, once that coming back end storage
look like, how are we mingling or

00:30:48.570 --> 00:30:49.337
not mingling our data?

00:30:49.337 --> 00:30:50.177
How are we mingling or

00:30:50.177 --> 00:30:54.867
not mingling our multiple storage paths
and access control mechanisms across them

00:30:54.867 --> 00:30:59.317
to ensure that only the LUNs that belong
to me are being shown to me as a customer.

00:30:59.317 --> 00:31:02.907
I should not be able to see or
mount another tenant's LUNs.

00:31:02.907 --> 00:31:05.358
A LUN is the logical unit
number the essential,

00:31:05.358 --> 00:31:09.250
virtual representation of
physical storage on the platform.

00:31:09.250 --> 00:31:14.420
So we take a storage array, huge bunch
of discs in a SAN where we may have x

00:31:14.420 --> 00:31:19.180
bytes of storage running in cabinets,
just row after row of storage

00:31:19.180 --> 00:31:22.510
that's essentially containerized,
just running in these large boxes.

00:31:22.510 --> 00:31:24.420
You've got thousands of spinning discs.

00:31:24.420 --> 00:31:27.370
I'm gonna virtually represent
a section of that, carve it off, and

00:31:27.370 --> 00:31:29.370
I'm gonna hand it to Daniel and
say, hey, here you go.

00:31:29.370 --> 00:31:30.740
Here's your storage.

00:31:30.740 --> 00:31:33.808
That is a LUN one or more of them
that we use to represent storage.

00:31:33.808 --> 00:31:37.450
In a SaaS model, I have to figure
out as the storage vendor,

00:31:37.450 --> 00:31:41.900
essentially the cloud provider, right, I
have to figure out how to do that without

00:31:41.900 --> 00:31:46.550
exposing his LUNs to me and without
exposing my data and my LUNs to him.

00:31:46.550 --> 00:31:48.783
Because if I can't zone and
mask appropriately,

00:31:48.783 --> 00:31:50.918
I have no way of controlling
that environment.

00:31:50.918 --> 00:31:56.698
>> If I send you out a storage path that
crosses my LUNs, you're gonna see my data.

00:31:56.698 --> 00:32:00.768
And I may have 100 storage paths for 100
different customers I have to manage, and

00:32:00.768 --> 00:32:04.343
if it's multi path there may be 3 or
4 instances that each of those customers

00:32:04.343 --> 00:32:07.973
potentially can use to access storage
on the backend because the redundancy,

00:32:07.973 --> 00:32:10.660
high availability and
things of that nature.

00:32:10.660 --> 00:32:13.120
So I have a really big,
very, very tough and

00:32:13.120 --> 00:32:17.350
very difficult job as an infrastructure
manager, as an architect on the Cloud for

00:32:17.350 --> 00:32:20.600
storage, if I'm working for
in one of these environments.

00:32:20.600 --> 00:32:24.220
Whereas the customer, I just show up and
say here's my money, I want my data.

00:32:24.220 --> 00:32:27.680
As a SAS provider I've
got a lot of problems.

00:32:27.680 --> 00:32:31.700
As a SAS customer all I gotta
do is to simply consume.

00:32:31.700 --> 00:32:32.930
So it's really about transference of risk,

00:32:32.930 --> 00:32:35.630
and where that risks resides
ultimately we have to worry about.

00:32:35.630 --> 00:32:40.550
So data access policies,
strict implementation of access control,

00:32:40.550 --> 00:32:45.100
validation, continuous monitoring,
these are things that we have to do.

00:32:45.100 --> 00:32:46.720
We have to demand, we have to expect.

00:32:46.720 --> 00:32:50.640
As Cloud surface providers on the
platform, as customers we have to validate

00:32:50.640 --> 00:32:53.630
they're happening thru third
party audits and attestation.

00:32:53.630 --> 00:32:56.300
Very, very important for
us to think about those things.

to make sure our environment is safe.

00:34:11.772 --> 00:34:15.758
And we've got to know what it is
we're making it safe from if we can't

00:34:15.758 --> 00:34:20.840
identify those things, then we're just
out there swinging our fists at the wind.

00:34:20.840 --> 00:34:22.604
It does a whole lot of nothing for us.

00:34:22.604 --> 00:34:25.350
Adam, we do appreciate you
pointing these out to us.

00:34:25.350 --> 00:34:28.220
And I really look forward to seeing
those top ten vulnerabilities

00:34:28.220 --> 00:34:29.270
in the next episode.

00:34:29.270 --> 00:34:30.620
Hopefully, you guys do as well.

00:34:30.620 --> 00:34:33.570
We thank you for dropping by and
we're gonna see you in the next episode.

00:34:33.570 --> 00:34:36.450
Hopefully we'll see you guys there as
well, we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

00:34:36.450 --> 00:34:38.950
For ITProTV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

>> And I'm Adam Gordon.

>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam spend time taking a look at the top 10 Application security risks; describing them one by one. They also explain the Cloud Data Security Life Cycle which helps us understand the phases that our data abides in at any given time. Finally they discuss Service Level Agreements(SLA) from a security and risk perspective, which is basically our contract of service with our cloud provider.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take a closer look at the Cloud Security Data Life Cycle phases. They explain what it takes to keep data secure at each one of these phases from securely storing to making sure that destroyed data is unrecoverable. They also talk about the idea of how secure a cloud solution is.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explain some considerations that need to be addressed when designing and implementing Cloud data storage architectures. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take you through designing and implementing relevant jurisdictional data protections for personally identifiable information. Superstorm Sandy, social engineering,
unauthorized facility access,

730
00:37:04.470 --> 00:37:07.480
default passwords being left in place and
being used, love that one, right?

731
00:37:07.480 --> 00:37:08.190
>> That's a fantastic.

732
00:37:08.190 --> 00:37:12.190
>> You can always walk up and
get on there, all sorts of stuff, right?

733
00:37:12.190 --> 00:37:16.160
And we talked about all these risks
because these are the areas that

734
00:37:16.160 --> 00:37:19.610
as certified cloud security professionals,
we have to think about and

735
00:37:19.610 --> 00:37:20.950
really be anticipating.

736
00:37:20.950 --> 00:37:24.800
This is that box that continues to grow
bigger and bigger as we talk about risk.

737
00:37:24.800 --> 00:37:29.090
And we have to anticipate and interact
with and operate in all of these areas to

738
00:37:29.090 --> 00:37:34.000
truly understand the kind of things that
we as CCSPs would deal with, but also that

739
00:37:34.000 --> 00:37:38.560
our customers that we are working with and
working for are gonna have to anticipate.

740
00:37:38.560 --> 00:37:41.580
And if they don't know about them, we have
to then figure out a way to communicate

741
00:37:41.580 --> 00:37:45.170
securely, communicate effectively
to them the value of planning and

742
00:37:45.170 --> 00:37:47.060
also the impact of risk in the business.

743
00:37:47.060 --> 00:37:48.230
It's very, very important.

744
00:37:48.230 --> 00:37:51.310
>> That's right, and while it is a risky
business getting into the cloud or

745
00:37:51.310 --> 00:37:55.810
any other type of computing environment,
and it's something we have to.

746
00:37:55.810 --> 00:37:57.887
We've seen today the importance
of risk analysis,

747
00:37:57.887 --> 00:38:00.635
we have to see where are we vulnerable,
and what can we do about that?

748
00:38:00.635 --> 00:38:03.508
And when you add the element
of the cloud you can remember,

749
00:38:03.508 --> 00:38:06.967
every component that you add to
your infrastructure, your network,

750
00:38:06.967 --> 00:38:10.560
your environment as a whole has its
own inherent risks involved with it.

751
00:38:10.560 --> 00:38:15.829
And you have to start looking and trying
to find them, so that you can a, mitigate

752
00:38:15.829 --> 00:38:21.710
those risks, and b, hopefully remove all
if you can, which is usually not possible.

753
00:38:21.710 --> 00:38:23.756
But as much as humanly possible,

754
00:38:23.756 --> 00:38:27.050
remove that element as being
a probable risk for you.

755
00:38:27.050 --> 00:38:28.768
And that's what it's all about,

756
00:38:28.768 --> 00:38:32.385
continually reevaluating,
reanalyzing the risks that are out there,

757
00:38:32.385 --> 00:38:36.140
and when it comes to our cloud
infrastructure, that is no different.

758
00:38:36.140 --> 00:38:39.888

out these things is something what we

759

we get to glean from that and

>> Stop, you're making me blush.

>> [LAUGH] He's going, stop, stop.

Certainly and I obviously always
appreciate the opportunity to talk and

765
00:38:55.276 --> 00:38:56.405
to talk about these things.

766
00:38:56.405 --> 00:39:00.150
One just quick thing in wrapping up to
remind you, I didn't mention defense in

767
00:39:00.150 --> 00:39:04.410
depth in this particular episode, but we
talk about it so many places and so often.

768
00:39:04.410 --> 00:39:06.360
It's incredibly important here,
especially.

769
00:39:06.360 --> 00:39:10.040
The overlapping mutually reinforcing
layers of control that we build, so

770
00:39:10.040 --> 00:39:13.515
that way if a risk happens in one area,
we haven't anticipated it, but

771
00:39:13.515 --> 00:39:16.595
we have a control somewhere else that
will offset the impact of that risk.

772
00:39:16.595 --> 00:39:19.495
We still are essentially
planning to be successful.

773
00:39:19.495 --> 00:39:20.645
And we really have to think about that.

774
00:39:20.645 --> 00:39:24.086
Because a lot of the risks we identified
are gonna occur across multiple systems

775
00:39:24.086 --> 00:39:25.845
and multiple areas at different times.

776
00:39:25.845 --> 00:39:30.035
And we may not always be in the right
place at the right time to respond.

777
00:39:30.035 --> 00:39:33.020
We may not always be in the right
place at the right time to anticipate.

778
00:39:33.020 --> 00:39:35.157
But if we have overlapping controls,

779
00:39:35.157 --> 00:39:39.835
mutually reinforcing systems that will
essentially defend one another, right,

780
00:39:39.835 --> 00:39:43.420
then we are more likely to be
successful at risk management.

781
00:39:43.420 --> 00:39:47.060
So we have to think about that, and
really, who's gonna trust the provider,

782
00:39:47.060 --> 00:39:49.640
who's gonna manage the provider
is one way to think about it.

783
00:39:49.640 --> 00:39:53.310
But more importantly, how are we as the
security professional and the provider,

784
00:39:53.310 --> 00:39:57.200
the cloud service provider, gonna work
together, to build a better infrastructure

785
00:39:57.200 --> 00:40:00.480
that is gonna be more risk resilient,
is really the question

786
00:40:00.480 --> 00:40:03.750
that we as CCSPs have to struggle
with as we wrap up our conversation.

787
00:40:03.750 --> 00:40:07.170
>> Building a security relationship
really with our cloud provider,

788
00:40:07.170 --> 00:40:08.800
that's what we're kind of getting at here.

789
00:40:08.800 --> 00:40:09.960
>> Yep.
>> Well, that being said,

790
00:40:09.960 --> 00:40:12.890
our clock has ticked away, and
we do appreciate you yet again.

791
00:40:12.890 --> 00:40:14.610
We appreciate you guys for
watching as well.

792
00:40:14.610 --> 00:40:17.700
Hopefully, you've gotten a lot out of
this episode, and maybe even enjoyed it.

793
00:40:17.700 --> 00:40:20.950
That being said, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

794
00:40:20.950 --> 00:40:22.910
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

795
00:40:22.910 --> 00:40:23.620
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

796
00:40:23.620 --> 00:40:26.102

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss the designing and planning of security controls. They start by looking at controlling the physical environment, including the building, support structures, and the physical devices themselves. Then they move on to looking at security control measures for the virtualization and communications systems.
episodes.title: Design and Plan Security Controls

64
00:02:48.560 --> 00:02:52.580
One of our data centers that we used to
host at years ago, we don't anymore, but

65
00:02:52.580 --> 00:02:56.720
as a company, globally, we used to,

It was actually a rated data center.

00:02:59.960 --> 00:03:02.470

although we did lease

69
00:03:04.980 --> 00:03:08.020
At the time we were going to the few
private customers that was there.

70
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:10.050
It was primarily for the government and

71
00:03:10.050 --> 00:03:12.840
the government was using
the majority of the data center.

72
00:03:12.840 --> 00:03:14.280
They had not built the data center,

73
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:17.290
but it was built to certain
specifications they required.

74
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:19.505
And when we gotta tour the data
center to decide with and

75
00:03:19.505 --> 00:03:20.635
how we wind up hosting there.

76

One of the interesting
things we found out, and

I mentioned this I think in other shows
for other discussions we've had, in CISSP.

78
00:03:27.425 --> 00:03:30.615
For instance [INAUDIBLE] some of
the other conversations we may or

00:03:30.615 --> 00:03:35.075
may not have had, over time I've
mentioned this particular data center,

it actually had kevlar built in

81
00:03:38.385 --> 00:03:43.680

And it was built that way specifically,

00:03:45.730 --> 00:03:50.720

an attack from outside the involved anti

They though that this may actually happen.

So the building was rated to actually
survive an external explosion of

89
00:04:08.630 --> 00:04:11.650

90
00:04:11.650 --> 00:04:14.310
Aside from all the normal protections
they put inside with everything else.

91
00:04:14.310 --> 00:04:15.320
So that was kind of cool.

92
00:04:15.320 --> 00:04:18.445
You could essentially take
a bazooka in just shoot it and

93
00:04:18.445 --> 00:04:21.665
you would not be able to breach the walls
either internally or externally, so.

94
00:04:21.665 --> 00:04:23.286
>> I want to be a part
of that testing process.

95
00:04:23.286 --> 00:04:23.857
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

00:04:23.857 --> 00:04:26.056
I wanted to be on site when they
were actually setting that up.

Al,l right George, stand the wall up,

let's test that before we
actually put the rest in place.

Let's make sure that anti tank round
does not go all the way through.

100
00:04:33.757 --> 00:04:34.787
>> Hot range [LAUGH].

101
00:04:34.787 --> 00:04:38.197
>> That's just kind of crazy, but
that's the kind of stuff sometimes

102
00:04:38.197 --> 00:04:41.677
that you see so physical infrastructure
obviously has to be considered.

103
00:04:41.677 --> 00:04:43.990
The environment around the data
center has to be considered.

104
00:04:43.990 --> 00:04:48.420
A lot of data centers actually are located
relatively close to fire houses or

105
00:04:48.420 --> 00:04:50.090
fire response systems, so

106
00:04:50.090 --> 00:04:54.720
that way if there is a fire, the emergency
responders can get there fairly quickly.

107
00:04:54.720 --> 00:04:58.520
You will find that they tend to be in
industrial areas more often than not.

108
00:04:58.520 --> 00:05:01.340
They are usually very large
nondescript buildings,

109
00:05:01.340 --> 00:05:04.160
hundreds of thousands of square
feet if they're commercial.

110
00:05:04.160 --> 00:05:06.930
And they're built to look
just like any other office or

111
00:05:06.930 --> 00:05:08.370
warehouse space around them.

112
00:05:08.370 --> 00:05:09.680
There's no fancy signs.

113
00:05:09.680 --> 00:05:13.980
We don't put up the, hey, save data
haven here sign or something like that.

114
00:05:13.980 --> 00:05:17.950
So there are generic buildings if you
know what to look for you will spot them.

115
00:05:17.950 --> 00:05:21.200
They do tend to have a lot of
cameras on the exterior so

116
00:05:21.200 --> 00:05:24.430
they tend to have a lot more security
maybe than some of these buildings do.

117
00:05:24.430 --> 00:05:28.580
They tend to be set back in such a way,
that there's not a lot around them.

118
00:05:28.580 --> 00:05:31.740
You can't drive right up to them,
it's gonna be an elevated platforms.

119
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:35.270
Or, raised in such a way that you
cannot drive from the street level,

120
00:05:35.270 --> 00:05:37.070
directly up to the front of the building.

121
00:05:37.070 --> 00:05:40.380
You can simply drive up and park,
but there's an elevated staircase or

122
00:05:40.380 --> 00:05:44.340
structure that lends itself to protecting
the building from direct attack.

123
00:05:44.340 --> 00:05:49.620
There may not be glass walls and/or
windows on the ground level, and

124
00:05:49.620 --> 00:05:50.130
if there are.

125
00:05:50.130 --> 00:05:53.670
It's simply in the admin space
away from the actual hosting area.

126
00:05:53.670 --> 00:05:56.420
Hosting area's typically
gonna be just concrete, and

127
00:05:56.420 --> 00:06:00.110
there's not gonna be any external
gateways or entry points there.

128
00:06:00.110 --> 00:06:03.000
External doors tend to be available, but

129
00:06:03.000 --> 00:06:06.500
they're available with no handles on
the outside for you to open, or pry open.

130
00:06:06.500 --> 00:06:09.260
They may be swipe card enabled,
so you can open them, but

131
00:06:09.260 --> 00:06:10.830
only under certain conditions.

132
00:06:10.830 --> 00:06:13.360
Or they're essentially one way doors,
they're made for exit.

133
00:06:13.360 --> 00:06:16.290
But you're not allowed to enter through
them and they tend to entry, or

134
00:06:16.290 --> 00:06:18.470
they tend to exit onto raised platforms.

135
00:06:18.470 --> 00:06:22.020
So, again, you can't walk right up
to the door and fiddle with it and

136
00:06:22.020 --> 00:06:23.230
they tend to be in the open.

137
00:06:23.230 --> 00:06:25.070
There's no landscaping around them.

138
00:06:25.070 --> 00:06:28.770
They're well-lit, with typically high
intensity lighting and cameras that

139
00:06:28.770 --> 00:06:33.270
are focused on the pad, where you exit
onto, the platform, so that anybody that's

140
00:06:33.270 --> 00:06:37.930
out there for any reason, is observed and
so these are the kind of design.

141
00:06:37.930 --> 00:06:41.280
Constraints that we see, and when you
start to look at these buildings and

142
00:06:41.280 --> 00:06:43.840
understand what they are and
you recognize them for

143
00:06:43.840 --> 00:06:47.300
what they are, you begin to see all
the security systems that are built in.

144
00:06:47.300 --> 00:06:50.310
They will have generators certainly
somewhere associated with them so

145
00:06:50.310 --> 00:06:55.040
you can tell when you see a 30-foot pad
with a couple of generators on it and

146
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:58.420
diesel tanks, that's obviously running
some pretty heavy-duty infrastructure.

147
00:06:58.420 --> 00:07:02.300
But they can be away from the building
because of the concerns about explosions,

148
00:07:02.300 --> 00:07:07.350
or the concerns about potentially somebody
taking that block of thermite and

149
00:07:07.350 --> 00:07:10.500
putting it right on the diesel tank and
setting it off, so things like that.

150
00:07:10.500 --> 00:07:13.750
Also because of noise generation and
things that are concerning there.

151
00:07:13.750 --> 00:07:16.810
We tend to see the infacts
systems not on ground level, but

152
00:07:16.810 --> 00:07:19.520
typically up on the roof,
which is not unusual in many buildings.

153
00:07:19.520 --> 00:07:21.360
But, they're up on the roof for
lots of reasons.

154
00:07:21.360 --> 00:07:24.030
Number one we don't want people
to go in and getting near them.

60 minutes of travel time, 30 miles or

696
00:34:42.010 --> 00:34:43.230
whatever it would have been.

697
00:34:43.230 --> 00:34:46.430
So if it was a fire then it wouldn't
have reached both sides simultaneously.

698
00:34:46.430 --> 00:34:49.970
If it was a hurricane or something, it
may have affected both sites at once, but

699
00:34:49.970 --> 00:34:52.860
the reality is while that may or
may not have been good enough, we would

700
00:34:52.860 --> 00:34:57.120
then hopefully have an alternate site that
was several hours away geographically so

701
00:34:57.120 --> 00:34:59.750
that way we are outside
that immediate impact zone.

702
00:34:59.750 --> 00:35:02.380
And this is the other thing we
gotta think about with cloud.

703
00:35:02.380 --> 00:35:05.590
Because cloud is so ubiquitous,
so always on so always available,

704
00:35:05.590 --> 00:35:08.430
we don't always think about the borders
and the geography of cloud because we

705
00:35:08.430 --> 00:35:11.730
essentially go out of our way to make sure
that we don't think of it that way and

706
00:35:11.730 --> 00:35:14.550
as a result it's kind of everywhere so
we don't think about it being anywhere.

707
00:35:14.550 --> 00:35:16.670
But this is one of the fallacies of cloud,

708
00:35:16.670 --> 00:35:19.180
just like the fallacies
associated with wireless.

709
00:35:19.180 --> 00:35:20.570
Wireless is not truly wireless.

710
00:35:20.570 --> 00:35:24.210
Wireless is semi wireless with
wired access on the back end.

711
00:35:24.210 --> 00:35:27.130
And we have to think about
cloud as being semi cloud.

712
00:35:27.130 --> 00:35:31.420
It is partially ubiquitous, partially
all available, partially borderless, but

713
00:35:31.420 --> 00:35:34.300
at some point you wind up
back on fixed infrastructure

714
00:35:34.300 --> 00:35:38.350
in an exact geographic location pinned
to the ground that isn't moving.

715
00:35:38.350 --> 00:35:41.690
And as a result of that, you've go to
understand that there is geography

716
00:35:41.690 --> 00:35:43.480
involved with managing the cloud.

717
00:35:43.480 --> 00:35:45.720
There is risk involved in that geography.

718
00:35:45.720 --> 00:35:48.280
And there is management of that risk

719
00:35:48.280 --> 00:35:51.050
that must be brought to bear in
order to understand how to recover.

720
00:35:51.050 --> 00:35:56.390
If I am recovering into the same geography
that the actual data site is in and

721
00:35:56.390 --> 00:35:59.110
the data site's blown out
by a catastrophic event,

722
00:35:59.110 --> 00:36:01.700
what do you think's going to
happen to my recover capability?

723
00:36:01.700 --> 00:36:04.140
It's going to be gone before
I even get to deploy it.

724
00:36:04.140 --> 00:36:06.610
I tell costumers all the time,
don't co-locate,

725
00:36:06.610 --> 00:36:10.210
don't fail over to where you
actually host primarily.

726
00:36:10.210 --> 00:36:16.260
I have customers in Florida,
South Florida that are hosting and then

727
00:36:16.260 --> 00:36:21.690
disaster recovering potentially within the
same geography 10, 20, 30, 40 miles away.

728
00:36:21.690 --> 00:36:24.930
You get a hurricane if you live in the
south or if you live in the south east or

729
00:36:24.930 --> 00:36:28.260
you live in the West Coast or
even in the Gulf states of the U.S.

730
00:36:28.260 --> 00:36:30.330
anywhere probably except North Dakota,
right?

731
00:36:30.330 --> 00:36:33.290
You pretty much know that
during hurricane season,

732
00:36:33.290 --> 00:36:34.610
you got to pay attention to the weather.

733
00:36:34.610 --> 00:36:37.690
But you also know the hurricanes
can be hundreds of miles long

734
00:36:37.690 --> 00:36:42.620
by a hundreds of miles wide and
they can move 20, 30, 40 miles an hour.

735
00:36:42.620 --> 00:36:45.770
These things are not moving quickly enough
you can't get out of their way, but

736
00:36:45.770 --> 00:36:48.640
they are big enough and moving
quickly enough that you can't pick up

737
00:36:48.640 --> 00:36:51.660
infrastructure and move it easily,
even if it's virtual.

738
00:36:51.660 --> 00:36:54.430
You still gotta worry about that,
because the carrying connections,

739
00:36:54.430 --> 00:36:58.945
the networks that connect you to where
you need to go, can be disrupted by that

740
00:36:58.945 --> 00:37:02.860
storm coming on shore across a five or
six hundred mile swath of territory.

741
00:37:02.860 --> 00:37:06.010
Basically from the tip of Florida
all the way up into Georgia.

742
00:37:06.010 --> 00:37:09.940
We get storms that are big enough they can
cover the entire state at one time and

743
00:37:09.940 --> 00:37:12.920
they will move 40 miles
an hour up the coast

744
00:37:12.920 --> 00:37:16.070
which means in several hours they
move to three or four states.

745
00:37:16.070 --> 00:37:19.460
It's very hard for you to get out
of the way of something like that.

746
00:37:19.460 --> 00:37:21.520
I would say it's impossible, right?

747
00:37:21.520 --> 00:37:24.825
So as a result, you gotta be
able to host in one location and

748
00:37:24.825 --> 00:37:27.690
fail over thousands of miles
away to another location.

749
00:37:27.690 --> 00:37:31.130
Because if you don't do that, chances
are good that that disaster recovery

750
00:37:31.130 --> 00:37:33.900
capability is going to be
impacted by the same event.

751
00:37:33.900 --> 00:37:36.810
And we just look at all the different
things that have happened around the world

752
00:37:36.810 --> 00:37:37.550
over the last five,

753
00:37:37.550 --> 00:37:41.760
ten, 20 years with this thought process
to learn from our mistakes, right?

754
00:37:41.760 --> 00:37:47.300
If you were in Fukushima when the reactor
melted down because of the Tsunami and

755
00:37:47.300 --> 00:37:50.740
you were anywhere in that general area
afterwards, you know you were done,

756
00:37:50.740 --> 00:37:52.050
there was really nowhere to go.

757
00:37:52.050 --> 00:37:54.460
Because you had radiation,
you had water damage,

758
00:37:54.460 --> 00:37:57.110
you had all sorts of catastrophic
things happening and

759
00:37:57.110 --> 00:38:02.340
it affected hundreds and thousands of
people, thousands of miles of territory.

760
00:38:02.340 --> 00:38:06.630
Same thing in the Ukraine when,
what's the nuclear power plant I'm

761
00:38:06.630 --> 00:38:08.250
thinking of from years
ago that melted down?

762
00:38:08.250 --> 00:38:09.420
>> You're talking about Chernobyl.

763
00:38:09.420 --> 00:38:10.140
>> Sure.
Thank you very much.

764
00:38:10.140 --> 00:38:11.680
Same thing with Chernobyl, right?

765
00:38:11.680 --> 00:38:12.460
It's the same idea.

766
00:38:12.460 --> 00:38:15.610
If you lived anywhere in that general
area, you were affected by it for 10, 20,

767
00:38:15.610 --> 00:38:16.870
30, 40, 100 miles around.

768
00:38:16.870 --> 00:38:20.280
It was a big deal, and so
you've got to think about these things.

769
00:38:20.280 --> 00:38:23.290
We don't think about nuclear power
plants melting down every day.

770
00:38:23.290 --> 00:38:25.320
That's not the typical
disaster we deal with.

771
00:38:25.320 --> 00:38:29.050
But the reality is a storm can take out
several thousand miles of territory

772
00:38:29.050 --> 00:38:32.570
over a 24, 48 hour run,
depending on what kind of storm it is.

773
00:38:32.570 --> 00:38:35.970
The north, if you think about the living
in the central part of the US,

774
00:38:35.970 --> 00:38:39.250
in the northern, central part of the US,
you deal with snow storms and

775
00:38:39.250 --> 00:38:39.990
ice storms certainly.

776
00:38:39.990 --> 00:38:41.940
If you think about the central US and

777
00:38:41.940 --> 00:38:44.619
the plain states, you think about
tornadoes and tornado alley.

778
00:38:45.760 --> 00:38:49.660
A category five tornado
ripping through a 40,

779
00:38:49.660 --> 00:38:52.920
50 miles swaff as it touches
the ground and then goes back again.

780
00:38:52.920 --> 00:38:56.640
In seconds can take out millions
of dollars in infrastructure.

781
00:38:56.640 --> 00:39:00.560
I mean, we're talking about 200 plus
winds and just tremendous damage.

782
00:39:00.560 --> 00:39:02.480
So, this is the kinda thing
we gotta worry about.

783
00:39:02.480 --> 00:39:05.050
Do we have the existing
on sights solutions,

784
00:39:05.050 --> 00:39:06.648
do we have them geographically dispersed?

785
00:39:06.648 --> 00:39:09.540
Have we pre-positioned
our recovery options?

786
00:39:09.540 --> 00:39:12.550
These are things we would definitely
want to be concerned with and

787
00:39:12.550 --> 00:39:17.430
wanna make sure that we are as CCSPs
really considering as part of the DR,

788
00:39:17.430 --> 00:39:20.240
the BCDR planning cycle
>> Well Adam this has been

789
00:39:20.240 --> 00:39:21.600
an enlightening episode.

790
00:39:21.600 --> 00:39:25.370
We've definitely gotta take a really good,
fine look at disaster recovery and

791
00:39:25.370 --> 00:39:26.410
business continuity.

792
00:39:26.410 --> 00:39:31.703
And thank you so much for helping us or
remove the veil, as it were, on what those

793
00:39:31.703 --> 00:39:36.618
exactly mean, so that we are able to
engage each one of them accordingly.

794
00:39:36.618 --> 00:39:39.339
That being said I know you got some more
information when it comes to this, so

795
00:39:39.339 --> 00:39:41.650
it looks like we're headed
to a part two in our future.

796
00:39:41.650 --> 00:39:43.950
And for this one we'll go ahead and
sign off.

797
00:39:43.950 --> 00:39:46.560
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

798
00:39:46.560 --> 00:39:47.520
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

799
00:39:47.520 --> 00:39:49.628
>> And we'll see you next time.

800
00:39:49.628 --> 00:39:57.070

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their dissertation on Disaster Recovery and Business Continuity. Here they pick back up by exploring the strategies that can be implemented toward forming a BCDR plan. Then they discuss the importance of testing the plan to discover possible issues and verify that the BCDR plan will actually work when needed.
episodes.title: Disaster, Recovery and Business Continuity Part 2

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.010 --> 00:00:10.010
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.186 --> 00:00:16.160
All right, greetings, everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.160 --> 00:00:21.055
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode we are continuing on

4
00:00:21.055 --> 00:00:24.488
with our certified
Cloud Security professionals.

5
00:00:24.488 --> 00:00:26.209
I got it right this time.

6
00:00:26.209 --> 00:00:27.856
>> Building that anticipation.

7
00:00:27.856 --> 00:00:28.372
I like that.
That was good.

8
00:00:28.372 --> 00:00:32.204
>> A pregnant pause that we throw in there
every now and then before that build up.

9
00:00:32.204 --> 00:00:34.826
But joining us back in the studio
again today to help us out,

10
00:00:34.826 --> 00:00:37.711
we're doing a Part Two,
a little bit on that disaster recovery,

11
00:00:37.711 --> 00:00:39.450
is our good friend, Mr. Adam Gordon.

12
00:00:39.450 --> 00:00:42.910
Adam, welcome back, I know we've got
some odds and ends to cover for DR.

13
00:00:42.910 --> 00:00:45.580
>> We do, so we're saying we're
doing Part Two of the disaster.

14
00:00:45.580 --> 00:00:49.930
So we're extending
the disaster into Part Two.

15
00:00:49.930 --> 00:00:53.650
So it was so good we brought it back for
a second run.

16
00:00:53.650 --> 00:00:56.600
So it's good to be back
here at Disaster Central.

17
00:00:56.600 --> 00:01:00.780
So let's talk a little bit more, as
Daniel was just indicating we need to do,

18
00:01:00.780 --> 00:01:04.580
about disaster, disaster recovery,
business continuity, and the general

19
00:01:04.580 --> 00:01:08.160
thought processes that we've been engaging
in in our prior episode around this.

20
00:01:08.160 --> 00:01:09.488
We left off talking about,

21
00:01:09.488 --> 00:01:13.485
right at the very end of the episode, the
idea that we are worried about geography.

22
00:01:13.485 --> 00:01:16.955
I made the point, I really stressed
the point that we should not recover

23
00:01:16.955 --> 00:01:19.495
into the same geography
that the disaster occurred.

24
00:01:19.495 --> 00:01:20.335
And if we can avoid it,

25
00:01:20.335 --> 00:01:23.345
because obviously there may be
liabilities associated with that.

26
00:01:23.345 --> 00:01:25.975
We may not have the ability
to provide power, long term,

27
00:01:25.975 --> 00:01:30.395
cuz maybe power disruption has been, or
power generation has been disrupted.

28
00:01:30.395 --> 00:01:35.030
Maybe communication is down because cell
towers are down and landlines have been

29
00:01:35.030 --> 00:01:37.750
compromised because they have been
knocked down off telephone poles or

30
00:01:37.750 --> 00:01:39.000
whatever the case may be.

31
00:01:39.000 --> 00:01:40.370
Does anybody still use landlines?

32
00:01:40.370 --> 00:01:43.830
Does anybody actually,
does anybody have an analog phone anymore?

33
00:01:43.830 --> 00:01:45.364
You know I struggle with this sometimes.

34
00:01:45.364 --> 00:01:49.100
[LAUGH] Because I talk to customers
a lot and I'm like cell phones and

35
00:01:49.100 --> 00:01:50.560
VOIP systems are all great, right?

36
00:01:50.560 --> 00:01:54.150
Think about the technology of the Cloud,
talk about real world for a minute, right?

37
00:01:54.150 --> 00:01:54.790
This is all good.

38
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:58.000
But what do you do when there's
a disruptive event that takes out

39
00:01:58.000 --> 00:02:01.110
the service provider or takes out
the cell sites because, at that point,

40
00:02:01.110 --> 00:02:01.700
you've got nothing.

41
00:02:01.700 --> 00:02:03.430
Do you guys have an actual land line?

42
00:02:03.430 --> 00:02:04.660
Do you have a wired phone?

43
00:02:04.660 --> 00:02:07.310
They look at you like you're nuts,
like what is an analog phone?

44
00:02:07.310 --> 00:02:09.230
What do you mean a land line, right?

45
00:02:09.230 --> 00:02:13.050
We don't have those things,
and years ago that was normal.

46
00:02:13.050 --> 00:02:16.400
You walked into a business, you picked
up a phone, it was an analog phone

47
00:02:16.400 --> 00:02:20.710
that was wired to an actual set of
cables that ran on telephone poles.

48
00:02:20.710 --> 00:02:22.740
Today we may or may not have that.

49
00:02:22.740 --> 00:02:24.210
Those lines may be buried of course.

50
00:02:24.210 --> 00:02:25.490
They may not be above ground anymore, but

51
00:02:25.490 --> 00:02:28.380
we may still have analog
systems that are running.

52
00:02:28.380 --> 00:02:31.510
We traditionally now, more often than not,
are using VoIP systems, and so

53
00:02:31.510 --> 00:02:36.530
this presents some very interesting
dilemmas for us from a BCDR perspective.

54
00:02:36.530 --> 00:02:40.370
How do we bring back old technology that's
tried and true, because we've gotten rid

55
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:42.980
of it because we thought it was so
archaic, when the reality is we may

56
00:02:42.980 --> 00:02:46.970
actually need that in the event that
there is a really bad disaster?

57
00:02:46.970 --> 00:02:49.260
I can remember several years ago.

58
00:02:49.260 --> 00:02:50.830
How long have you lived in Florida?

59
00:02:50.830 --> 00:02:51.910
>> I have lived here since 1985.

60
00:02:51.910 --> 00:02:54.076
>> All right, so you've been here for
a, I can't do the math, but for

61
00:02:54.076 --> 00:02:54.650
a very long time.

62
00:02:54.650 --> 00:02:56.252
>> 30 years.
>> Yes, I could figure that out.

63
00:02:56.252 --> 00:02:56.782
I was just being facetious.

64
00:02:56.782 --> 00:02:57.390
So you've been here for awhile.

65
00:02:57.390 --> 00:03:02.815
But you lived up here for
the most part, in this general area?

66
00:03:02.815 --> 00:03:05.720
>> Yeah, well,
I was born down in the Broward area but

67
00:03:05.720 --> 00:03:06.680
we moved up here [CROSSTALK].

68
00:03:06.680 --> 00:03:08.205
>> Okay, so you were born down in Broward.

69
00:03:08.205 --> 00:03:11.390
So I don't know how long you
would have been down in Broward,

70
00:03:11.390 --> 00:03:12.230
how old you were when you moved.

71
00:03:12.230 --> 00:03:15.720
But we've had some significant storms,
right, in South Florida in particular.

72
00:03:15.720 --> 00:03:17.680
They've certainly effected
this area as well.

73
00:03:17.680 --> 00:03:19.930
But not as often, not as much, and

74
00:03:19.930 --> 00:03:22.570
maybe not as disruptive,
depending on the kind of storm it was.

75
00:03:22.570 --> 00:03:25.702
>> If you think of Andrew, [CROSSTALK]
>> Well Andrew certainly would, sure,

76
00:03:25.702 --> 00:03:28.395
it did tremendous damage down south,
didn't really come up here,

77
00:03:28.395 --> 00:03:30.130
didn't do much damage up here at all.

78
00:03:30.130 --> 00:03:33.110
>> But I'm thinking, after Andrew,
but Andrew's a good example.

79
00:03:33.110 --> 00:03:35.930
And I'm thinking not Andrew, I forget
the name of the storm that occurred.

80
00:03:35.930 --> 00:03:43.145
It was many years after Andrew, but
it was in Miami in Broward, in Palm Beach.

81
00:03:43.145 --> 00:03:46.575
Excuse me, didn't really come up here
much, but and it wasn't like a huge,

82
00:03:46.575 --> 00:03:49.375
huge, huge storm that did mega damage, but

83
00:03:49.375 --> 00:03:52.905
it was very catastrophic with regards
to just taking out infrastructure.

84
00:03:52.905 --> 00:03:57.265
And so, at the time when it came through,
what happened was we had a lot of rain,

85
00:03:57.265 --> 00:03:59.680
a lot of wind actually more so
than anything else, and

86
00:03:59.680 --> 00:04:03.200
we lost power which tends to happen in
most storms, that's not a big deal.

87
00:04:03.200 --> 00:04:07.630
We lost power, so traffic lights are out,
lights are out, all that kind of stuff.

88
00:04:07.630 --> 00:04:12.280
And as a result of that,
we lost cell towers because, at the time,

89
00:04:12.280 --> 00:04:16.910
prior to the storm happening, as is
the case even today, most cell towers have

90
00:04:16.910 --> 00:04:20.950
backup power but they have UPSs that
run on batteries for several hours.

91
00:04:20.950 --> 00:04:22.380
They're meant to go down for
a period of time,

92
00:04:22.380 --> 00:04:27.180
and typically power is restored more often
than not, and the towers don't go offline.

93
00:04:27.180 --> 00:04:30.920
While this power outage was extensive and
took days to recover from,

94
00:04:30.920 --> 00:04:33.980
and as a result of that
the cell sites all went down.

95
00:04:33.980 --> 00:04:36.880
So within about three or
four hours of the storm going by,

96
00:04:36.880 --> 00:04:39.630
when power stopped,
all the cell sites went dead so

97
00:04:39.630 --> 00:04:43.368
you couldn't get a phone dial tone
on your cellphone if you tried.

98
00:04:43.368 --> 00:04:47.380
The landlines, if there were any, were
all down because you had to have either

99
00:04:47.380 --> 00:04:52.120
Internet access to use your phone in many
cases, or because of the power outages,

100
00:04:52.120 --> 00:04:55.370
there was essentially no power to
run the repeater sites, and so

101
00:04:55.370 --> 00:04:56.550
everything was down.

102
00:04:56.550 --> 00:04:57.920
And on top of it,

103
00:04:57.920 --> 00:05:02.040
you couldn't get gas from the gas stations
cuz there was no power to power the pumps.

104
00:05:02.040 --> 00:05:05.330
And at the time, this actually changed
in the state of Florida since then,

105
00:05:05.330 --> 00:05:09.050
before this happened there was no law
in the books that said you must have

106
00:05:09.050 --> 00:05:10.680
emergency generation capabilities,

107
00:05:10.680 --> 00:05:15.080
power generation capabilities at critical
infrastructure sites beyond just the UPS.

108
00:05:15.080 --> 00:05:16.960
You actually have to
have a backup generator.

109
00:05:16.960 --> 00:05:20.950
Now most gas stations actually have
small little backup generators, but

110
00:05:20.950 --> 00:05:22.960
enough power to be able
to power the pumps.

111
00:05:22.960 --> 00:05:25.600
So if there's power that you
essentially don't have, you lose,

112
00:05:25.600 --> 00:05:28.760
because the pumps are driven by power.

113
00:05:28.760 --> 00:05:31.795
You have to have electricity, in other
words, to get gas out of the the ground.

114
00:05:31.795 --> 00:05:35.885
You actually now can actually still
get gas if gas is in the tanks

115
00:05:35.885 --> 00:05:37.405
during this event or after this event.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore the necessity of building secure applications. They begin the discussion by looking at cloud development of both RESTful and SOAP apps and common pitfalls to avoid. They also discuss the SDLC or Software Development Life-Cycle.
