I mean, this is just smart
application development,

747
00:38:20.190 --> 00:38:21.750
whether we're in the cloud or not.

748
00:38:21.750 --> 00:38:24.600
And we use threat modeling all
the time outside of the cloud, but

749
00:38:24.600 --> 00:38:27.840
it becomes especially important
in the cloud cuz we don't control

750
00:38:27.840 --> 00:38:32.440
as many of the parameters in the cloud
as we do on-prem when we run this app

751
00:38:32.440 --> 00:38:35.810
isolated on our systems behind
the firewall on the lab.

752
00:38:35.810 --> 00:38:38.050
So it becomes even more critical for

753
00:38:38.050 --> 00:38:42.690
us as security professionals to focus
on threat modeling and to inject that

754
00:38:42.690 --> 00:38:46.500
threat modeling thought process into the
secure application development life cycle.

755
00:38:46.500 --> 00:38:51.890
So into the secure SDLC, very,
very important for us to consider here.

756
00:38:51.890 --> 00:38:56.782
>> Well, Adam, this has been a whelming
flood of information when it comes

757
00:38:56.782 --> 00:38:58.637
to securing our programs.

758
00:38:58.637 --> 00:39:01.033
Right, we're creating
APIs on a daily basis.

759
00:39:01.033 --> 00:39:02.241
We do it here on ITProTV,

760
00:39:02.241 --> 00:39:06.630
as millions of companies probably across
the world that are creating them as well.

761
00:39:06.630 --> 00:39:10.025
And it's a cool thing that we have
a community of people that say,

762
00:39:10.025 --> 00:39:12.140
you know what, we are security minded.

763
00:39:12.140 --> 00:39:16.627
We need to come at our software
with that in mind as well.

764
00:39:16.627 --> 00:39:20.076
You can't just create an application,
throw it out into the wild, and

765
00:39:20.076 --> 00:39:21.870
expect everything to be hunky dory.

766
00:39:21.870 --> 00:39:22.904
You have to-
>> You can, but

767
00:39:22.904 --> 00:39:25.945
as evidence to the contrary shows,
you shouldn't is what we should say.

768
00:39:25.945 --> 00:39:26.855
>> There you go.

769
00:39:26.855 --> 00:39:28.855
>> You could, but we should not,
is what we would want to say.

770
00:39:28.855 --> 00:39:30.110
>> Thank you for the correction, sir.

771
00:39:30.110 --> 00:39:30.648
>> Absolutely.

772
00:39:30.648 --> 00:39:33.000
>> And that's something we want to avoid.

773
00:39:34.030 --> 00:39:37.160
If you create an application, it's
basically a gateway for every bad hacker

774
00:39:37.160 --> 00:39:42.180
out there to jump and grab data, or
use your systems in a malicious way.

775
00:39:42.180 --> 00:39:44.720
Then you've really done
the world a disservice.

776
00:39:44.720 --> 00:39:45.880
You've done yourself a disservice.

777
00:39:45.880 --> 00:39:47.470
You've done your clients a disservice.

778
00:39:47.470 --> 00:39:52.190
And that's why we put a lot of
emphasis on creating secure APIs.

779
00:39:52.190 --> 00:39:53.810
Obviously, it's a lot of information.

780
00:39:53.810 --> 00:39:55.720
There's gonna be training
involved with that.

781
00:39:55.720 --> 00:39:58.520
If you're a software developer you
have to stay on top of that thing, but

782
00:39:58.520 --> 00:40:00.264
again we've got things
that we can lean on.

783
00:40:00.264 --> 00:40:02.900
The OS model, the STRIDE threat models,

784
00:40:02.900 --> 00:40:05.295
to make sure that we are following
a set of guidelines and

785
00:40:05.295 --> 00:40:10.615
procedures that will help us do that very
thing, and create secure applications.

786
00:40:10.615 --> 00:40:14.005
Adam, thank you so much for
pointing this out to us, and

787
00:40:14.005 --> 00:40:16.855
as always, giving me a good
correction when necessary.

788
00:40:16.855 --> 00:40:17.975
>> No problem.
>> [LAUGH]

789
00:40:17.975 --> 00:40:19.225
>> We thank you guys for watching.

790
00:40:19.225 --> 00:40:20.455
We are gonna go ahead and sign off.

791
00:40:20.455 --> 00:40:23.355
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

792
00:40:23.355 --> 00:40:24.970
>> I am a secure API.

793
00:40:24.970 --> 00:40:27.831
>> [LAUGH] And we'll see you next time.

794
00:40:27.831 --> 00:40:35.400
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss the necessity of using software that has been verified as secure and then look at Identity and Access Management(IAM) solutions. They explain secure software by way of looking at approved APIs, supply-chain management, and open-source/community software. They describe IAM design by discussing Federated IDs, ID providers, Single Sign-On(SSO), and the use of multi-factor authentication.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Management Solutions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

00:00:00.258 --> 00:00:10.258
[MUSIC]

00:00:12.486 --> 00:00:16.656
>> Greetings, everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

00:00:16.656 --> 00:00:20.594
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode, we are continuing forward with

00:00:20.594 --> 00:00:24.437
our Certified Cloud Security Professional
series and I did get it right that time.

00:00:24.437 --> 00:00:28.228
Joining us back in the studio again today
to help us out with that very endeavor and

00:00:28.228 --> 00:00:31.603
lend his expertise on that topic is
our good friend, Mr. Adam Gordon.

00:00:31.603 --> 00:00:32.417
Adam, welcome back, sir.

00:00:32.417 --> 00:00:32.945
How's it going?

00:00:32.945 --> 00:00:34.774
>> A legend in your own mind you are.

00:00:34.774 --> 00:00:38.224
I'm running to move forward
constant in the cloud.

00:00:38.224 --> 00:00:40.337
I'm backstroking through the cloud,
as we go.

00:00:40.337 --> 00:00:41.597
Look, look, no hands.

00:00:41.597 --> 00:00:44.519
>> Peter Pan.
No feet., I'm standing.

00:00:44.519 --> 00:00:45.941
But there are no feet, cuz there's no mat.

00:00:45.941 --> 00:00:48.293
Anyway, I'll get back to what
we're talking about here.

00:00:48.293 --> 00:00:50.148
It's the end of the day,
we're getting silly.

00:00:50.148 --> 00:00:54.280
So we have to keep talking about secure
application development in the cloud and

00:00:54.280 --> 00:00:57.499
think about using verified
secure software, and identity.

00:00:57.499 --> 00:00:59.780
And access management,
which is an activity and

00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:03.185
a topic that we love to talk about here
with regards of risks in the cloud.

00:01:03.185 --> 00:01:05.889
Comes up yet
again in many of the topics we have.

00:01:05.889 --> 00:01:08.634
When we think about using
secure verified software,

00:01:08.634 --> 00:01:10.714
we've talk a lot about API's already.

00:01:10.714 --> 00:01:13.237
We circle back to this idea yet again.

00:01:13.237 --> 00:01:18.500
You're using approved API's is so
important, so critical for us to consider.

00:01:18.500 --> 00:01:20.436
The challenge for
the cloud security provider and

00:01:20.436 --> 00:01:23.288
the cloud security professional,
both and the customer.

00:01:23.288 --> 00:01:26.940
All three is what equals approved.

00:01:26.940 --> 00:01:29.344
Who approves it who says,
the API is valid?

00:01:29.344 --> 00:01:30.662
Is it the security provider?

00:01:30.662 --> 00:01:33.992
Is it the cloud provider,
in other words, that is doing that?

00:01:33.992 --> 00:01:36.280
Is it the customer that approves APIs?

00:01:36.280 --> 00:01:36.859
Typically not.

00:01:36.859 --> 00:01:38.665
Is it the provider?

00:01:38.665 --> 00:01:40.519
More often than not.

00:01:40.519 --> 00:01:44.264
And if they are approving it, but they
don't necessarily explain to us why, how,

00:01:44.264 --> 00:01:46.527
when, who and
all the things associated with it.

00:01:46.527 --> 00:01:47.969
How do we as the customer know?

00:01:47.969 --> 00:01:50.148
And how do we know that
approved equals secure?

00:01:50.148 --> 00:01:52.821
Because approved doesn't
always equal secure,

00:01:52.821 --> 00:01:55.694
approved simply equals,
essentially authorized.

00:01:55.694 --> 00:01:58.800
Valid, but
that doesn't always mean secure.

00:01:58.800 --> 00:02:01.146
And so, there's a lot of issues
associated with the use of APIs.

00:02:01.146 --> 00:02:04.600
They are insecure code
libraries that exist out there.

00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:06.121
And if the coding is not done correctly,

00:02:06.121 --> 00:02:09.938
we've already established in prior
episodes that this can lead to risk and

00:02:09.938 --> 00:02:13.346
ultimately to threat and
vulnerability and we may have exposure.

00:02:13.346 --> 00:02:16.770
We may have web application
based vulnerabilities,

00:02:16.770 --> 00:02:19.182
the top ten list from OAuth or
wherever we may look for those.

00:02:19.182 --> 00:02:23.966
And we may see concerns, especially for
things like injection attacks,

00:02:23.966 --> 00:02:27.994
cross site request forgery,
cross site scripting attacks.

00:02:27.994 --> 00:02:29.905
XSS and XXRF and injection attacks and

00:02:29.905 --> 00:02:33.260
all sorts of other things that we
would have to be concerned about.

00:02:33.260 --> 00:02:36.910
So, we really have to
think about this right.

00:02:36.910 --> 00:02:40.901
Programatic control and access, automation
integration with third party tools.

00:02:40.901 --> 00:02:44.532
These are all the benefits that
potentially exist with the use of APIs,

00:02:44.532 --> 00:02:47.754
but they're also potentially
detriments that exist as well.

00:02:47.754 --> 00:02:50.865
The APIs are not vetted and
are not created securely.

00:02:50.865 --> 00:02:54.596
The consumption of APIs if done
incorrectly can lead to an insecure

00:02:54.596 --> 00:02:57.710
environment, we have to think about this.

00:02:57.710 --> 00:03:00.490
So for instance, when I go in and

00:03:00.490 --> 00:03:05.620
I use Office 365 as I do for my business.

00:03:05.620 --> 00:03:09.527
I am the tenant manager of
a many of the Office 365 real

00:03:09.527 --> 00:03:12.378
estate items that we have going on.

00:03:12.378 --> 00:03:16.490
We've got about six or seven under the
different names we do business with and

00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:21.280
plus for many of my customers, I advise
them on how to use the platform securely.

00:03:21.280 --> 00:03:26.200
When I login, I'm able to actually
go in and to see the organizational

00:03:26.200 --> 00:03:32.173
dashboard if you will for Office 365 that
is the tenant admin I have rights to.

00:03:32.173 --> 00:03:36.846
And because of that, I can login and
I can see all the service updates.

00:03:36.846 --> 00:03:38.693
I can see all the open tickets.

00:03:38.693 --> 00:03:41.450
I can see the users that are in there.

00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:43.470
I can see the state of licensing.

00:03:43.470 --> 00:03:46.930
The consumption of services,
look at reporting,

00:03:46.930 --> 00:03:49.391
look at all the different things
that are associated with that.

00:03:49.391 --> 00:03:54.722
But I do so through a web API, as all of
us do if we use this kind of a service.

00:03:54.722 --> 00:03:58.528
When I login, when I am doing that, I'm
just going to actually not show it to you,

00:03:58.528 --> 00:04:00.290
but I am going to just pull it up.

00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:03.644
So I can talk to you about it while
we're talking on my screen here, but

00:04:03.644 --> 00:04:04.329
I use HTTPS.

00:04:04.329 --> 00:04:09.979
I'm using a secure version of Web Access
through the API that Microsoft provides.

00:04:09.979 --> 00:04:11.884
They've got their URL there.

00:04:11.884 --> 00:04:16.619
I'm using Internet Explorer right now, but
I could just as easily be using Chrome and

00:04:16.619 --> 00:04:19.468
I'm able to access it with
Chrome with no trouble.

00:04:19.468 --> 00:04:22.815
It actually looks essentially the same,
it works essentially the same way and

00:04:22.815 --> 00:04:23.634
is just as secure.

00:04:23.634 --> 00:04:28.340
When I do those things and
I'm actually accessing and

00:04:28.340 --> 00:04:34.117
being able to get in with a secure API,
everything hopefully works well.

00:04:34.117 --> 00:04:38.475
I can look at the certificate chain and
look at the trust associated with that,

00:04:38.475 --> 00:04:41.184
and I can validate that
I'm logged in securely,

00:04:41.184 --> 00:04:44.750
and I can know beyond a reasonable
doubt that I'm going to be able

00:04:44.750 --> 00:04:48.130
to rely on the security
associated with this connection.

00:04:48.130 --> 00:04:52.709
But if I'm using an insecure API, if I'm
not using a web API that has been offered

00:04:52.709 --> 00:04:56.785
by the vendor and is validated,
I may not have that sense of security,

00:04:56.785 --> 00:05:00.269
that sense of well-being that
I need to have as a customer.

00:05:00.269 --> 00:05:04.675
And ultimately, as a security
professional to allow this to occur.

00:05:04.675 --> 00:05:09.220
So when I deal with web providers,
when I deal with cloud providers and

00:05:09.220 --> 00:05:10.530
web app providers,

00:05:10.530 --> 00:05:15.401
you wanna first things we ask as a
customer is what APIs are you supporting?

00:05:15.401 --> 00:05:18.655
Please give us an authorized list
of APIs you want us to use, so

00:05:18.655 --> 00:05:21.673
we understand how to connect
securely to your platform.

00:05:21.673 --> 00:05:24.146
It's very important for
my customers to know that.

00:05:24.146 --> 00:05:26.548
Because that way, if Firefox, for

00:05:26.548 --> 00:05:30.640
instance is on the list and
Safari is not as an Apple browser.

00:05:30.640 --> 00:05:34.422
Then if we use Safari or at least if we
attempt to use Safari while we may get

00:05:34.422 --> 00:05:38.180
good results and may be able to connect,
we should be aware of the fact

00:05:38.180 --> 00:05:42.235
that we're connecting with a non-supported
application interface that may or

00:05:42.235 --> 00:05:44.422
may not render and use the API correctly.

00:05:44.422 --> 00:05:47.460
And that's a risk, and
we have to document that risk, and

00:05:47.460 --> 00:05:50.330
that's a liability that the organization
may or may not want to take on.

00:05:50.330 --> 00:05:52.348
We may look at that and say, unacceptable.

00:05:52.348 --> 00:05:55.664
We have a usage policy that says,
only these browsers.

00:05:55.664 --> 00:06:00.392
These applications are supported, because
we're worried about the secure application

00:06:00.392 --> 00:06:02.516
of that API correctly to the interface.

00:06:02.516 --> 00:06:05.688
This is very important for
us as CCSPs to understand.

00:06:05.688 --> 00:06:09.468
>> So Adam, the approval comes from
the internal entity itself and

00:06:09.468 --> 00:06:12.624
not necessarily some third
party approving entity.

00:06:12.624 --> 00:06:13.967
>> Well, it depends.

00:06:13.967 --> 00:06:15.866
So the approval can come from both places,

00:06:15.866 --> 00:06:18.624
it depends on the nature of
the APM what we're talking about.

00:06:18.624 --> 00:06:22.990
So if you remember one of our prior
episodes, I asked you to go out and

00:06:22.990 --> 00:06:26.358
look up XAML and look up OAuth and
we went to for XAML,

00:06:26.358 --> 00:06:30.136
specifically went to the XAML,
XML org site and we saw it.

00:06:30.136 --> 00:06:33.140
I mentioned that Oasis was
the group right kinda behind that,

00:06:33.140 --> 00:06:36.376
that group that is the industry
group that manages that standard,

00:06:36.376 --> 00:06:38.948
puts out all the information,
coordinates it all.

00:06:38.948 --> 00:06:42.480
They're not approving quote,
unquote, the API directly.

00:06:42.480 --> 00:06:47.297
But what they are doing is offering
the information, the coordination and

00:06:47.297 --> 00:06:51.274
the maintenance of the standards
that lead to OAuth or XACML or

00:06:51.274 --> 00:06:53.429
XAML or OpenID or whatever it is.

00:06:53.429 --> 00:06:55.600
Pick your trade group, whatever it may be.

00:06:55.600 --> 00:06:56.117
But ultimately,

00:06:56.117 --> 00:07:00.204
they are putting out the standard
that then is either used directly to

00:07:00.204 --> 00:07:04.930
implement the API or is used as reference
to build the secure APIs to align with.

00:07:04.930 --> 00:07:07.202
So, they are definitely a third party.

00:07:07.202 --> 00:07:09.745
In this case,
playing a part in that in some respects.

00:07:09.745 --> 00:07:15.910
Then you add in vendors that are providing
web services billed with those standards.

00:07:15.910 --> 00:07:19.130
So whether it's Microsoft,
whether its Google whether it's Amazon,

00:07:19.130 --> 00:07:19.980
whoever they are.

00:07:19.980 --> 00:07:22.938
They're gonna add their two
cents in essentially and

00:07:22.938 --> 00:07:26.158
then they're gonna provide,
essentially a certified or

00:07:26.158 --> 00:07:29.305
authorized vision of that
API to their customers.

00:07:29.305 --> 00:07:33.348
You use this browser with this
web address and this port map and

00:07:33.348 --> 00:07:35.389
whatever and we support that.

00:07:35.389 --> 00:07:38.789
We don't support as we were just saying
maybe let's not pick on Apple, cuz it's

00:07:38.789 --> 00:07:42.100
been a long day and I've already picked
on your Apple choice a couple of times.

00:07:42.100 --> 00:07:44.278
So let's say, Firefox is not supported.

00:07:44.278 --> 00:07:45.374
So, Safari is.

00:07:45.374 --> 00:07:48.296
So, we may or
may not want Safari to be used.

00:07:48.296 --> 00:07:50.827
We may have other options, but
it's on the authorized list.

00:07:50.827 --> 00:07:52.448
So at least we know if it is used,

00:07:52.448 --> 00:07:55.344
it's used securely whereas
Firefox should not be used.

00:07:55.344 --> 00:07:59.276
So, we now have the vendor playing
a part and adding their part in.

00:07:59.276 --> 00:08:03.366
And then we also have to create a policy
as the customer, if we're smart anyway.

00:08:03.366 --> 00:08:08.127
And we are risk-adverse, and we are doing
our job as CCSPs, we would educate and

00:08:08.127 --> 00:08:10.927
hopefully encourage,
politely encourage and

00:08:10.927 --> 00:08:16.500
perhaps coerce if they're not paying
attention, our customer, our organization.

00:08:16.500 --> 00:08:21.400
To draft a policy that will implement
ultimately through process and procedure

00:08:21.400 --> 00:08:25.730
the standardization of the consumption
of that API that is supported and

00:08:25.730 --> 00:08:30.390
is deemed to be secure by the third
party's standards organization.

00:08:30.390 --> 00:08:33.180
And the vendor both have kinda
added their two cents in right,

00:08:33.180 --> 00:08:35.300
and come up with this solution.

00:08:35.300 --> 00:08:39.340
We're now gonna consume that, and
we're gonna mandate that consumption, and

00:08:39.340 --> 00:08:42.700
coordinate that from the governance and
a compliance perspective.

00:08:42.700 --> 00:08:45.409
So it takes a village, right,
[LAUGH] if you think about it this way.

00:08:45.409 --> 00:08:47.716
It takes a village to add
all these moving parts in.

00:08:47.716 --> 00:08:50.800
Now, is it always done that way?

00:08:50.800 --> 00:08:50.930
It may or may not be.

00:08:50.930 --> 00:08:53.820
Do we really acknowledge
the fact that Oasis or

00:08:53.820 --> 00:08:57.230
whatever the group is behind
a certain standard has put it out?

00:08:57.230 --> 00:08:58.720
We probably, as the consumer,

00:08:58.720 --> 00:09:03.210
unless we're an educated consumer, a cloud
security professional such as any of you,

00:09:03.210 --> 00:09:07.510
an IT professional such as Daniel or
myself or whoever, any of you also out

00:09:07.510 --> 00:09:11.000
there that may be listening to this if you
fall into one or more of those categories.

00:09:11.000 --> 00:09:13.000
We may be knowledgable enough to know,
right?

00:09:13.000 --> 00:09:15.900
But the reality is the customers you had,
the individual users,

00:09:15.900 --> 00:09:17.540
the farm bureau years ago.

00:09:17.540 --> 00:09:20.280
Did most of them know much
about the technology other than

00:09:20.280 --> 00:09:23.110
you told them this is how they use it and
this is what they do?

00:09:23.110 --> 00:09:24.850
I'm guessing, I'm guessing, probably not.

00:09:24.850 --> 00:09:25.670
You're shaking you're head.

00:09:25.670 --> 00:09:28.820
>> You guessed right, you're shaking
your head yes, vigorously off camera.

00:09:28.820 --> 00:09:30.980
So, chances are good probably not, right?

00:09:30.980 --> 00:09:35.900
So does the average customer, does the
average consumer of a cloud service really

00:09:35.900 --> 00:09:36.890
get all the things we just described?

00:09:36.890 --> 00:09:38.360
They just know, right?

00:09:38.360 --> 00:09:40.660
The only thing they do know is
that it works when it works, and

00:09:40.660 --> 00:09:42.140
it doesn't when it doesn't right?

00:09:42.140 --> 00:09:44.910
Remember, the customer wants simplicity.

00:09:44.910 --> 00:09:48.790
The customer wants lack of risk,
and lack of acceptance of risk, and

00:09:48.790 --> 00:09:50.140
just functionality.

00:09:50.140 --> 00:09:52.700
They just wanna know that it works.

00:09:52.700 --> 00:09:55.240
They don't wanna accept risk,
they don't wanna be told all the issues.

00:09:55.240 --> 00:09:58.550

the enclave into our trust zone.

00:22:30.231 --> 00:22:34.656
And allow them operate inside there
as trusted members of our enclave.

00:22:34.656 --> 00:22:38.531
We're extending our trust to them and
they to us, in return, cuz typically,

00:22:38.531 --> 00:22:42.173
federation winds up being, although
it can always be a one way solution,

00:22:42.173 --> 00:22:45.987
it may very well be a two way solution,
where I may trust you, as a vendor, and

00:22:45.987 --> 00:22:47.410
you may also trust me.

00:22:47.410 --> 00:22:50.900
So I can access your real time
online provisioning system for

00:22:50.900 --> 00:22:54.670
just in time ordering, and I give
you access to my inventory system so

00:22:54.670 --> 00:22:56.600
that the two can,
essentially, communicate.

00:22:56.600 --> 00:22:59.420
And when I put an order in, you can
validate that to make sure I haven't

00:22:59.420 --> 00:23:01.780
missed anything, and
that I've ordered enough.

00:23:01.780 --> 00:23:05.830
And you can self-correct and autocorrect
that so that the inventory matches.

00:23:05.830 --> 00:23:08.900
And I've always got pre-determined
levels of what I want.

00:23:08.900 --> 00:23:09.840
And you make sure I have that on-hand.

00:23:09.840 --> 00:23:11.890
And this is what's done in
a lot of systems today.

00:23:11.890 --> 00:23:13.953
>> So it becomes collaborative.

00:23:13.953 --> 00:23:14.686
It can.

00:23:14.686 --> 00:23:18.346
>> A good way to think about it it becomes
collaboration and federation typically

00:23:18.346 --> 00:23:22.228
implies collaboration at some level but
we're gonna be doing these things in order

00:23:22.228 --> 00:23:25.580
to be able to make sure that we
are extending trust to both parties.

00:23:25.580 --> 00:23:28.910
The supply vendor has to trust
me to come into their CRM or

00:23:28.910 --> 00:23:32.610
not the CRM system rather their ERP
system, their inventory management and

00:23:32.610 --> 00:23:36.190
ordering system, at least the front end
of it anyway that their customer sees.

00:23:36.190 --> 00:23:38.840
And I as the customer have
to trust them to come in and

00:23:38.840 --> 00:23:43.280
look at my inventory database,
whatever my ERP equivalent it.

00:23:43.280 --> 00:23:46.590
And I have to give each other, we have
to give each other access that we can

00:23:46.590 --> 00:23:49.600
essentially collaborate how this
communication taking place.

00:23:49.600 --> 00:23:51.835
But it's about extending trust so
we have to think about this.

00:23:51.835 --> 00:23:53.476
We use standards typically to do this.

00:23:53.500 --> 00:23:56.500
We've mentioned SAML several times,
query research and

00:23:56.489 --> 00:23:58.156
markup language is used by far.

00:23:58.156 --> 00:24:02.650
Probably the most commonly accepted
standard today in our industry to do this.

00:24:02.650 --> 00:24:06.858
We also use WS-Federation, Web Service
Federation, OpenID we've mentioned,

00:24:06.858 --> 00:24:10.238
Oauth, Oauth 2,
we've mentioned a lot of these.

00:24:10.238 --> 00:24:14.850
These are gonna be standards that are used
for identity and access management.

00:24:14.850 --> 00:24:18.725
As a CCSP you should be aware of these
standards, you should know what they are.

00:24:18.725 --> 00:24:20.549
Can you, while we're talking?

00:24:20.549 --> 00:24:22.790
>> [LAUGH].

00:24:22.790 --> 00:24:23.847
>> It's okay.

00:24:23.847 --> 00:24:28.618
>> [SOUND] Can you, while we're talking,
Google WS-Federation?

00:24:28.618 --> 00:24:30.890
And when you have a link
to the OASIS page.

00:24:30.890 --> 00:24:33.910
Just being that up, or let me know,
and we'll bring that up real quick.

00:24:33.910 --> 00:24:36.760
I just want to show the good
people out there in our

00:24:36.760 --> 00:24:39.530
audience what that standard looks like.

00:24:39.530 --> 00:24:41.780
So while we're waiting for
that to come up, you got that?

00:24:41.780 --> 00:24:42.960
So can we take a look real quick?

00:24:42.960 --> 00:24:44.150
There we go.

00:24:44.150 --> 00:24:50.500
So when we take a look at WS-Federation
a later, excuse me, I'm gonna try again.

00:24:50.500 --> 00:24:53.400
An earlier standard that came out before
some of the others we're talking about,

00:24:53.400 --> 00:24:56.610
but you can see WS-Federation,
web service federation language

00:24:56.610 --> 00:24:59.890
is also used pretty common standard
that we often reference as well.

00:24:59.890 --> 00:25:03.220
Again, through OASIS, OASIS is it's
gonna be that glue on the back and

00:25:03.220 --> 00:25:05.490
it holds a lot of this stuff
together in this area.

00:25:05.490 --> 00:25:07.720
So wanna make sure you're
familiar with this as well.

00:25:07.720 --> 00:25:11.240
Yet another one that you just may wanna
know underneath the idea of identity in

00:25:11.240 --> 00:25:12.410
access management.

00:25:12.410 --> 00:25:16.740
We talk about identity providers and
relying parties.

00:25:16.740 --> 00:25:20.640
The identity provider is gonna be
the provider or the entity that

00:25:20.640 --> 00:25:24.860
holds all the identities and generates
the token that identifies a known user.

00:25:24.860 --> 00:25:29.370
That's the identity provider
may very well be, for instance,

00:25:29.370 --> 00:25:32.560
the ADDS in Windows, the Microsoft
Active Directory directory service,

00:25:32.560 --> 00:25:36.190
is the identity provider that's gonna
generate the user identities and

00:25:36.190 --> 00:25:38.400
validate them that's what
that function will be.

00:25:38.400 --> 00:25:42.200
And then the relying party, what's called
the RP in the language of identity and

00:25:42.200 --> 00:25:46.940
access management, is the service provider
that consumes those identity tokens

00:25:46.940 --> 00:25:48.980
to authenticate users and allow them in.

00:25:48.980 --> 00:25:53.993
So the relying party may be the
Microsoft Azure fabric that's using that

00:25:53.993 --> 00:25:59.105
token to validate the user, to give
them access to services on the cloud.

00:25:59.105 --> 00:26:00.811
That would be the relying party.

00:26:00.811 --> 00:26:04.805
It's the service provider that consumes
the user identity to provide access.

00:26:04.805 --> 00:26:08.545
As opposed to the identity provider
that actually creates the identity and

00:26:08.545 --> 00:26:12.730
validates it for the users so that they
can then use that or exchange that for

00:26:12.730 --> 00:26:13.830
access to cloud services.

00:26:13.830 --> 00:26:16.700
So we wanna make sure we
understand the language here.

00:26:16.700 --> 00:26:17.960
And definitely understanding and

00:26:17.960 --> 00:26:22.770
how to differentiate between identity,
provider and realigned party.

00:26:22.770 --> 00:26:26.700
Underneath identity providers is a general
category within the identity and

00:26:26.700 --> 00:26:29.460
access management discussion,
is gonna be very important for

00:26:29.460 --> 00:26:32.470
you when you think about preparing for
the CSSP exam.

00:26:32.470 --> 00:26:34.330
We also talk about single sign on.

00:26:34.330 --> 00:26:40.160
Access all and authenticate once, right,
login authenticate one time, access many.

00:26:40.160 --> 00:26:41.360
Think of it various ways.

00:26:41.360 --> 00:26:44.530
The idea is that we are going to
provide our creditor up front.

00:26:44.530 --> 00:26:47.460
And once we've done that and authenticated
it, we're not gonna then have to worry

00:26:47.460 --> 00:26:50.390
about having to reauthenticate
typically to every system.

00:26:50.390 --> 00:26:53.130
We're simply gonna present
a representation of that so

00:26:53.130 --> 00:26:55.370
that we know that we
are an authenticated user and

00:26:55.370 --> 00:26:58.950
that we could resume those services
once we've authenticated in.

00:26:58.950 --> 00:27:02.150
This generically is the idea of SSO or
single sign on.

00:27:02.150 --> 00:27:03.350
We use this all the time today.

00:27:03.350 --> 00:27:05.700
In Windows we implement
this through Kerberos,

00:27:05.700 --> 00:27:10.330
in most web services, we use single
sign on with Federation to validate and

00:27:10.330 --> 00:27:12.820
then propagate it out to various systems.

00:27:12.820 --> 00:27:14.730
This is very common in the cloud today.

00:27:14.730 --> 00:27:18.138
We, as security professionals,
need to understand the value of SSO, but

00:27:18.138 --> 00:27:20.950
also the architecture that goes
into building SSO systems and

00:27:20.950 --> 00:27:23.730
the necessary requirements on
the back end to support them.

00:27:23.730 --> 00:27:30.360
Things like WS Federation, things like
Open ID, OLAF 2.0, XACML, XAML, etc.

00:27:30.360 --> 00:27:33.828
You gotta know that these things
are associated with an SSO environment and

00:27:33.828 --> 00:27:35.445
understand how they work.

00:27:35.445 --> 00:27:39.150
When we think about authenticating,
we've talked about single

00:27:39.150 --> 00:27:42.470
versus dual versus multi factor
authentication at various points.

00:27:42.470 --> 00:27:45.100
I've inserted this into conversations.

00:27:45.100 --> 00:27:48.760
It's always relevant to talk about here
with identity and access management.

00:27:48.760 --> 00:27:51.279
Remember the idea's that we can
authenticate, that we can provide.

00:27:52.380 --> 00:27:57.430
The vision of our identity, who we are,
and represent that in a variety of ways.

00:27:57.430 --> 00:27:59.470
We simply talk about
that three common ways,

00:27:59.470 --> 00:28:03.400
something we have, something we know,
and something we are.

00:28:03.400 --> 00:28:07.650
And so when we think those acceptable
ways of identifying ourselves,

00:28:07.650 --> 00:28:10.230
we're talking about factors
of our identification.

00:28:10.230 --> 00:28:14.345
A single factor is one of those, dual
factor is two of the three, mix and match,

00:28:14.345 --> 00:28:19.520
multi-factor sometimes incorrectly
it's used to refer to both dual and

00:28:19.520 --> 00:28:21.600
all three being joined together.

00:28:21.600 --> 00:28:25.300
So you will hear multi-factor when
people may really mean dual-factor.

00:28:25.300 --> 00:28:28.100
But you hear multi-factor for
either dual or all three.

00:28:28.100 --> 00:28:29.460
Up to you, mix and match.

00:28:29.460 --> 00:28:31.580
But ultimately if all
three factors are used,

00:28:31.580 --> 00:28:33.950
it's considered multi-factor
authentication.

00:28:33.950 --> 00:28:37.360
So I have no R, so let's quickly
talk about an example of each.

00:28:37.360 --> 00:28:41.730
So if we have something, that could be
something we have in our possession,

00:28:41.730 --> 00:28:45.200
it could be a smart card for instance
that we insert into a smartcard reader.

00:28:45.200 --> 00:28:49.340
That would be a form or
an identity factor with something we have.

00:28:49.340 --> 00:28:53.650
Something we know, could be a PIN
number that goes with the smart card.

00:28:53.650 --> 00:28:54.780
Could be a user name and

00:28:54.780 --> 00:28:58.140
a password, it's something knowledge
that we have that we have to provide.

00:28:58.140 --> 00:29:03.000
And then if it's something we are,
that's a biometric solution of some kind.

00:29:03.000 --> 00:29:08.780
That could be something like a iris scan
or retina scan, something of that nature.

00:29:08.780 --> 00:29:10.840
There's combinations of
those that can be used.

00:29:10.840 --> 00:29:14.100
We can do a retina scan along
with a smart card swipe, right?

00:29:14.100 --> 00:29:17.220
Something like that could be done for
dual factor authentication.

00:29:17.220 --> 00:29:19.460
The trick here is to
understand couple of things.

00:29:19.460 --> 00:29:21.890
Number one that, obviously,
the more factors for

00:29:21.890 --> 00:29:26.900
authentication we provide, the stronger
the likelihood that the individual on

00:29:26.900 --> 00:29:29.350
the far side of that equation is
legitimately who they claim to be.

00:29:29.350 --> 00:29:33.200
And therefore more likely that we're gonna
validate a user that is an authorized user

00:29:33.200 --> 00:29:36.350
that should be allowed in,
less likely we'll get a bad after,

00:29:36.350 --> 00:29:37.650
is what I'm suggesting.

00:29:37.650 --> 00:29:41.220
Did you see, or have you seen,
the most recent Mission Impossible movie?

Came out a year or more ago, now?

>> No, I did not see that.

>> So, interesting cuz in that movie,
right,

00:29:49.540 --> 00:29:51.680
they actually do a really
cool thing with biometrics.

00:29:51.680 --> 00:29:54.970
So at a certain point,
without spoiling the entire plot, but

00:29:54.970 --> 00:29:59.700
at a certain point they've got
the IMF team has to sneak in to

a highly secure area to essentially,

steal some sort of information

And so they've gotta pretend to be
somebody they're not to authenticate in

and essentially go in and trick the guards

So one of the guys has to

right, they generate the mask.

They do the voice thing, all that.

like chambers that you walk into,

It's like 30 feet long or whatever.

So it's actually kinda cool cuz

And this is not something

But they actually showed a movie as

Cuz you don't normally

00:31:51.660 --> 00:31:53.462
So that part,

It was something you know,
something you have something you have,

00:31:55.600 --> 00:31:56.390
something you are,

all joined together that they do all three

And the biometric part, the something

>> Yeah and multi factor authentication
is becoming quite common anymore nowadays

00:32:07.190 --> 00:32:07.930
anywhere.

I mean Don does it just to log into

>> That's because Don's cool, I wanna
be like Don when I grow up he's cool,

that's why he does that.

>> But it's easy to do, it's not as

is always nice to have and make sure
that you've got things on lockdown.

00:32:32.930 --> 00:32:34.170
>> Correct, but with one caveat.

So the issue there is not cost,
as you said, it has come down.

It's not availability,

The challenge, the only thing,

So I agree 100% will as Daniel just said.

But with one caveat, which is

it's easier but
the one chance we still have not overcome

00:32:54.600 --> 00:32:58.120
is the awareness of the users and
the ability to train them to understand

00:32:58.120 --> 00:33:01.212
that they can use these systems and
that they are gonna be receptive to it.

00:33:01.212 --> 00:33:04.670
So, when you say to somebody, hey we're
gonna shoot a light in your eye and

00:33:04.670 --> 00:33:08.350
we're gonna expect you to scan to do that,

you're out of your mind right?

>> [LAUGH]
>> It's not happening.

Now we know that light going
your eye is not gonna harm you,

we know that's not gonna be an issue.

But when you tell somebody,
we're gonna put a light

00:33:19.200 --> 00:33:23.150
Into the back of your eye to scan
the retina or to scan the iris,

00:33:23.150 --> 00:33:26.310

to that no matter how cheap it is,

00:33:26.310 --> 00:33:30.300
no matter how cool it is, no matter how

So it may still be a problem even

00:33:34.735 --> 00:33:36.185
unfortunately, in all reality,

is still the hurdle we have to
overcome there, more often than not.

Finished a look in at

00:20:58.480 --> 00:21:01.800
This is called
Runtime Application Self-Protection.

00:21:01.800 --> 00:21:03.750
And the idea with RASP is
that we're focusing on

00:21:03.750 --> 00:21:08.500
the ability of the applications that
are built to have self-protection and

00:21:08.500 --> 00:21:10.990
really see, because not all applications
are built this way first of all, so

00:21:10.990 --> 00:21:13.950
not all applications can be using RASP.

00:21:13.950 --> 00:21:17.490
But the newer ones that are that
are self-healing and have self-protection

00:21:17.490 --> 00:21:22.630
capabilities, where they can modify their
code or in some way change out their code

00:21:22.630 --> 00:21:27.610
to reflect that an attack has happened and
to swap out bad files back for good.

00:21:27.610 --> 00:21:32.260
So for instance, in the Microsoft Windows
operating system, since probably

00:21:32.260 --> 00:21:37.600
Windows Vista and certainly in Windows
7 and Windows 8, 8.1, Windows 10,

00:21:37.600 --> 00:21:41.500
we have self healing capabilities,
we have this in Microsoft Office.

00:21:41.500 --> 00:21:45.724
Since I think 2007 or Office 2010 as well,
where the system can pull back down DLLs

00:21:45.724 --> 00:21:49.710
and essentially fix itself if we find
there's been an error in the code.

00:21:49.710 --> 00:21:53.510
We can do this and we have self-protection
capabilities built into the runtime

00:21:53.510 --> 00:21:55.380
environments of certain applications and

00:21:55.380 --> 00:22:00.180
if we do that, we're gonna be able to
essentially see the application logic,

00:22:00.180 --> 00:22:05.390
the data flow, the event information,
and track event flows.

00:22:05.390 --> 00:22:09.460
And we prevent attacks by
reconfiguring the application or

00:22:09.460 --> 00:22:11.950
changing it on the fly automatically.

00:22:11.950 --> 00:22:16.540
This is almost like an IPS, and
intrusion prevention system, being used.

00:22:16.540 --> 00:22:19.400
But it's the application itself,
that's the IPS.

00:22:19.400 --> 00:22:22.771
And as I go to attack the application,
the application reconfigures and

00:22:22.771 --> 00:22:27.116
as such it creates a, defends a perimeter
around itself, preventing the malware or

00:22:27.116 --> 00:22:30.370
preventing the bad act or
whatever from gaining control.

00:22:30.370 --> 00:22:34.330
And that way we don't have to
worry about faults or threats and

00:22:34.330 --> 00:22:37.445
having to respond to them ourselves
because we may be too slow.

00:22:37.445 --> 00:22:39.905
The application can actually
do that on our behalf.

00:22:39.905 --> 00:22:42.945
So this is runtime application
self-protection called RASP.

00:22:42.945 --> 00:22:45.405
This is a newer thought-process,
newer concept but

we actually can use this as an additional

00:31:38.950 --> 00:31:41.735
And looking at all the different
categories we've just talked about in

00:31:41.735 --> 00:31:44.645
the OWASP area for
knowledge of the application.

00:31:44.645 --> 00:31:46.175
It's environment, it's dependencies,

00:31:46.175 --> 00:31:48.105
and all the things that
are associated with it.

00:31:48.105 --> 00:31:51.250
We always trying to understand
the broadest possible picture,

00:31:51.250 --> 00:31:54.450
the broadest possible brush
strokes with regards to the risks.

00:31:54.450 --> 00:31:57.640
Picture that we paint in
the organization and don't forget to put

00:31:57.640 --> 00:32:01.340
root cause analysis and the knowledge
of root cause into that context.

00:32:01.340 --> 00:32:05.180
Because that's really often the missing
piece and if we can think all the time and

00:32:05.180 --> 00:32:08.630
logically, about how we achieve
root cause awareness and

00:32:08.630 --> 00:32:12.580
how we can understand root cause and the
importance that gives us, the framework it

00:32:12.580 --> 00:32:15.730
gives us and the understanding
the broad guidance it gives us.

00:32:15.730 --> 00:32:19.430
With regards to the enterprise
architecture, right,

00:32:19.430 --> 00:32:22.690
the enterprise security architecture,
we paint that picture but

00:32:22.690 --> 00:32:24.660
sometimes very narrowly defined.

00:32:24.660 --> 00:32:25.800
We're talking about an application.

00:32:25.800 --> 00:32:27.460
Let's just test that one application.

00:32:27.460 --> 00:32:28.890
Let's make sure we know how that works.

00:32:28.890 --> 00:32:30.300
That's important, but

00:32:30.300 --> 00:32:32.880
what about that application in
the broad context of the business?

00:32:32.880 --> 00:32:34.200
What is it gonna touch?

00:32:34.200 --> 00:32:34.920
What is it gonna interact with?

00:32:34.920 --> 00:32:36.880
Who's gonna use it under what conditions?

00:32:36.880 --> 00:32:38.100
What data will it produce?

00:32:38.100 --> 00:32:39.490
How do we store that data securely?

00:32:39.490 --> 00:32:41.640
How do we transmit that data securely?

00:32:41.640 --> 00:32:44.120
How do we safeguard that
data over its life cycle?

00:32:44.120 --> 00:32:47.270
How do we dispose of the data securely
at the end of that life cycle.

00:32:47.270 --> 00:32:52.370
These are the broader implications of
the enterprise security architecture.

00:32:52.370 --> 00:32:56.620
And root cause analysis helps us to really
put that picture into perspective and

00:32:56.620 --> 00:32:57.250
understand it.

00:32:57.250 --> 00:32:59.540
So if I could offer you
any additional guidance,

00:32:59.540 --> 00:33:01.740
it would be to really always
understand and remember.

00:33:01.740 --> 00:33:05.150
The value of root cause and the value
of the enterprise security architecture

00:33:05.150 --> 00:33:09.340
as the all up answers to questions
that put context on the table and

00:33:09.340 --> 00:33:11.330
create our ability to
understand where we are,

00:33:11.330 --> 00:33:14.220
with regards to that context throughout
the organization at all times.

00:33:14.220 --> 00:33:17.300
>> Well Adam we sure appreciate
that guidance and we appreciate.

00:33:17.300 --> 00:33:20.450
I'll give yourself that for watching but
it looks like we've wrapped up yet

00:33:20.450 --> 00:33:21.990
another episode here in ITProTV.

00:33:21.990 --> 00:33:23.430
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

00:33:23.430 --> 00:33:25.700
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

00:33:25.700 --> 00:33:27.300
>> I have not been then.

00:33:27.300 --> 00:33:28.510
Or who've I've been today?

00:33:28.510 --> 00:33:31.320
I have been a self-protecting application.

00:33:31.320 --> 00:33:32.520
That's what I've been today.

00:33:32.520 --> 00:33:34.580
>> [LAUGH] And because of that,
we'll see you next time.

00:33:34.580 --> 00:33:35.580
Have a good one, everyone.

00:33:35.580 --> 00:33:36.729
>> Take care everybody.

NOTE end of file

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss the ways in which we can implement security from the onset of implementation of our physical infrastructure. They start by exploring the secure-by-design physical components that can/should be used in the build, including TPM, secure storage controllers, and network controllers. Finally they go over some of the baked-in security features of the virtualization management tools.
episodes.title: Implement and Build Physical Infrastructure
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

00:00:00.234 --> 00:00:10.234
[MUSIC]

00:00:12.970 --> 00:00:16.265
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

00:00:16.265 --> 00:00:19.391
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode, that's right,

00:00:19.391 --> 00:00:23.130
we are continuing with our Certified
Cloud Security Professional series.

00:00:23.130 --> 00:00:26.500
Joining us back in the studio again to
lend his expertise on that very topic,

00:00:26.500 --> 00:00:27.740
our good friend, Mr. Adam Gordon.

00:00:27.740 --> 00:00:29.960
Adam, welcome back to the show and
how's it going?

00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:31.130
>> Good,
I'm feeling a little blonde today.

00:00:31.130 --> 00:00:32.130
>> Feeling a little blonde?

00:00:32.130 --> 00:00:34.100
>> I don't know.
We were having that whole conversation,

00:00:34.100 --> 00:00:35.900
made me stop and think, boy.

00:00:35.900 --> 00:00:36.745
>> You would look good blonde I think.

00:00:36.745 --> 00:00:38.500
>> No.
>> I say we do it.

00:00:38.500 --> 00:00:38.985
>> No, I would not.

00:00:38.985 --> 00:00:40.835
I'm looking forward to meeting your wife,

00:00:40.835 --> 00:00:42.975
I'm not looking forward to
meeting the dive model.

00:00:42.975 --> 00:00:43.718
>> She'll bring the bleach.

00:00:43.718 --> 00:00:46.000
[LAUGH]
>> I'm not looking forward to that.

00:00:46.000 --> 00:00:49.325
But anyway, we're not here to
talk about hair color choices.

00:00:49.325 --> 00:00:49.864
We are here to talk about
enterprise operations and

00:00:49.864 --> 00:00:50.409
how we're gonna ultimately implement and
build.

00:00:54.520 --> 00:00:56.350
Or at least talk about how
we should implement and

00:00:56.400 --> 00:00:58.500
build physical infrastructure for
the cloud.

00:00:58.500 --> 00:01:00.000
From the CCSPs perspective,

00:01:00.300 --> 00:01:04.590
as we think about what we have to do to be
secure across the cloud infrastructure,

00:01:04.590 --> 00:01:09.460
across the cloud enterprise, we have to
make sure that our thoughts, our concerns,

00:01:09.460 --> 00:01:12.690
the concerns from a security
standpoint are voiced early

00:01:12.690 --> 00:01:17.220
in the process of building up to the cloud
before we start actually using the cloud.

00:01:17.220 --> 00:01:21.800
So we're really, at this point, focusing
on what are the data center issues and

00:01:21.800 --> 00:01:23.720
concerns, we spoke about
those in our prior episode.

00:01:23.720 --> 00:01:26.620
We're gonna take a look now at
some of the architecture elements,

00:01:26.620 --> 00:01:28.870
the enterprise operation areas.

00:01:28.870 --> 00:01:32.615
What are best practices from setting
up secure storage, how we multipath,

00:01:32.615 --> 00:01:35.610
how we decide what we're gonna do and
how we're gonna do it.

00:01:35.610 --> 00:01:40.170
So as we begin to think through what
the architecture will be we can insert

00:01:40.170 --> 00:01:43.300
secure design elements along the way.

00:01:43.300 --> 00:01:46.880
To make sure that as we do ultimately
consume in the cloud, we are able to do so

00:01:46.880 --> 00:01:48.570
in the most secure way possible.

00:01:48.570 --> 00:01:49.950
>> Adam would you say in the design,

00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:54.500
in the building phase, that we really
want to start with a security foundation

00:01:54.500 --> 00:01:57.695
instead of trying to slap security on,
after we've built something?

00:01:57.695 --> 00:02:00.115
>> So it's always better,
always better to,

00:02:00.115 --> 00:02:04.115
if possible, to Daniel's point,
to build security in from the beginning.

00:02:04.115 --> 00:02:05.565
We talk about securing early and

00:02:05.565 --> 00:02:08.495
securing often when we talk
about security engineering.

00:02:08.495 --> 00:02:12.410
And the idea there is that if we're
able to interdict in that development

00:02:12.410 --> 00:02:16.773
cycle early in the SDLC, in the actual
requirements gathering phase, before we

00:02:16.773 --> 00:02:21.370
actually even get to design, we can be
right at the beginning of that process.

00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:25.867
And we can insert the security concerns
and the security thought processes we need

00:02:25.867 --> 00:02:30.837
to have represented throughout design,
development, testing, ultimately into

00:02:30.837 --> 00:02:36.140
secure operations and the management of
the lifecycle out through secure disposal.

00:02:36.140 --> 00:02:39.240
We can interdict at every one
of those phases with security

00:02:39.240 --> 00:02:41.470
instead of bolting it on after the fact.

00:02:41.470 --> 00:02:44.164
It's always more effective,
it's always more cost effective,

00:02:44.164 --> 00:02:46.628
it's always easier to implement,
it's easier to manage.

00:02:46.628 --> 00:02:51.900
And it yields better results at the end of
the day because it's intuitively built in.

00:02:51.900 --> 00:02:55.915
As opposed to being slapped together right
and added on where it may not integrate

00:02:55.915 --> 00:03:00.945
properly, may not be as cohesive and may
not be as far reaching an all consuming

00:03:00.945 --> 00:03:04.635
and all encompassing with it's support and
ultimately with its coverage, right?

00:03:04.635 --> 00:03:08.251
So there's not doubt about it,
it's a great point to make that we want

00:03:08.251 --> 00:03:12.150
to try to have security built in early and
build in often if we can.

00:03:12.150 --> 00:03:16.111
From an enterprise operation standpoint,
we have to think about, and

00:03:16.111 --> 00:03:18.160
I've made this reference several times.

00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:23.660
With regards to are we running private
cloud on-prem versus outsourcing

00:03:23.660 --> 00:03:28.240
cloud essentially to a hosting model
through a CSP, a cloud service provider.

00:03:28.240 --> 00:03:31.755
If we're doing private on cloud,
I keep saying private on cloud.

00:03:31.755 --> 00:03:32.520
>> You did.

00:03:32.520 --> 00:03:33.470
>> We should just rename that that.

00:03:33.470 --> 00:03:34.790
>> You're going to build that one day.

00:03:34.790 --> 00:03:37.952
>> We should just rename that, I just I
think I should be able to say that it's

00:03:37.952 --> 00:03:40.808
now called private on cloud as
opposed to private on-prem cloud.

00:03:40.808 --> 00:03:42.991
Cuz for me, that would be so
much easier, and

00:03:42.991 --> 00:03:45.110
it really is it's all about me after all.

00:03:45.110 --> 00:03:48.888
So if it's going to be
private on-prem cloud, right?

00:03:48.888 --> 00:03:51.860
And we're gonna own
the infrastructure ourselves,

00:03:51.860 --> 00:03:54.940
IT in the business is providing cloud for
the business.

00:03:54.940 --> 00:03:57.000
That's what we essentially are describing.

00:03:57.000 --> 00:04:00.990
When we think about enterprise operations
from this perspective, we have to stop and

00:04:00.990 --> 00:04:05.540
understand that everything we do, all the
security issues and concerns we address,

00:04:05.540 --> 00:04:10.530
all the policies, the procedures, all
the technology, is all gonna come from us.

00:04:10.530 --> 00:04:14.650
It's gonna be internal, and we have to
decide how to deploy, how to manage,

00:04:14.650 --> 00:04:17.440
and ultimately how to allow for
secure consumption.

00:04:18.450 --> 00:04:21.665
If we are doing this through
some sort of outsource model,

00:04:21.665 --> 00:04:25.700
where a third party cloud provider
who's gonna provide the infrastructure.

00:04:25.700 --> 00:04:30.000
And we're going to remotely manage and
consume across that infrastructure.

00:04:30.000 --> 00:04:33.990
We have to partner to achieve
the enterprise operational security

00:04:33.990 --> 00:04:35.170
standpoint that we need.

00:04:35.170 --> 00:04:39.890
We have to in other words come up with
a way to jointly recognize our vision.

00:04:39.890 --> 00:04:42.390
And we have to work with
that cloud provider

00:04:42.390 --> 00:04:45.100
in order to make sure
that they can detail for

00:04:45.100 --> 00:04:48.520
us upfront what the expectations
are from a security standpoint.

00:04:48.520 --> 00:04:49.610
What do they provide?

00:04:49.610 --> 00:04:50.760
What technology?

00:04:50.760 --> 00:04:54.770
What capabilities, under what
conditions can we access the cloud?

00:04:54.770 --> 00:04:59.610
And with what expectation of control and
what expectation of security?

00:04:59.610 --> 00:05:03.900
And then we have to allow that
information to sink in and

00:05:03.900 --> 00:05:07.760
integrate that into our planning and our
management and our documentation cycles.

00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:09.540
So we should think about
the best practices,

00:05:09.540 --> 00:05:11.350
traditionally of secure build, right?

00:05:11.350 --> 00:05:15.180
Secure initial config and
ultimately secure ongoing configuration.

00:05:15.180 --> 00:05:16.900
The idea of security
that Daniel spoke about,

00:05:16.900 --> 00:05:19.800
building in at every level, every layer.

00:05:19.800 --> 00:05:22.540
When we build out infrastructure for the
cloud, envision what that looks like and

00:05:22.540 --> 00:05:23.650
build it securely.

00:05:23.650 --> 00:05:27.400
Use vendors that are on approved
resource acquisition lists.

00:05:27.400 --> 00:05:31.110
Use authorized hardware that will run
on the platform, that's been tested.

00:05:31.110 --> 00:05:35.524
Maybe you go out and
look at the common criteria, ISO 15408.

00:05:35.524 --> 00:05:38.600
And maybe you decide you're gonna buy or

00:05:38.600 --> 00:05:41.220
acquire infrastructure that
has been certified and

00:05:41.220 --> 00:05:45.740
evaluated at a certain protection
level under the common criteria.

00:05:45.740 --> 00:05:49.810
So you want that EAL,
the Evaluation Assurance Level rating.

00:05:49.810 --> 00:05:53.956
Of EAL4, so you're gonna only buy
infrastructure at that level for

00:05:53.956 --> 00:05:55.110
your cloud.

00:05:55.110 --> 00:05:57.990
These are things, decisions,
choke points, right?

00:05:57.990 --> 00:05:59.420
In the architecture of the build and

00:05:59.420 --> 00:06:03.980
design phases that as CCSP's we
have to be constantly aware of,

00:06:03.980 --> 00:06:07.890
constantly monitoring, and
deciding how we should proceed forward.

00:06:07.890 --> 00:06:10.257
When we think about secure
initial configuration,

00:06:10.257 --> 00:06:14.360
we gotta think about things like host
hardening, host patching, host lockdown.

00:06:14.360 --> 00:06:17.950
These are concepts that will be important
for us to implement and consider.

00:06:17.950 --> 00:06:19.920
Strip out all unnecessary services.

00:06:19.920 --> 00:06:25.200
Ensure that all necessary and required
patches have not only been approved and

00:06:25.200 --> 00:06:27.240
tested, but have also been applied.

00:06:27.240 --> 00:06:29.990
Make sure that we are applying
secure templates and

00:06:29.990 --> 00:06:34.370
secure baseline configurations to
our host, and to our VMs by the way,

00:06:34.370 --> 00:06:37.670
our guest operating systems running
on them if we're virtualizing.

00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:42.320
And make sure that we use continuous
monitoring to not only initially

00:06:42.320 --> 00:06:47.920
configure, but then to monitor or to
look at that configuration over time and

00:06:47.920 --> 00:06:50.130
ensure it is going to be
continuously applied.

00:06:50.130 --> 00:06:53.970
If it's not and we see a gap or a delta,
some deviation, that we are warned or

00:06:53.970 --> 00:06:55.980
alerted and we can then remediate.

00:06:55.980 --> 00:06:57.810
These are all things that
we have to think about.

00:06:57.810 --> 00:07:02.880
Ongoing configuration maintenance is about
baseline management and random sampling

00:07:02.880 --> 00:07:06.820
to ensure governance and compliance
with the proper security solutions.

00:07:06.820 --> 00:07:10.560
All of these things would be important for
the CCSP to be thinking about.

00:07:10.560 --> 00:07:14.950
And as we've talked about in many other
places in the episodes we've done,

00:07:14.950 --> 00:07:17.400
this is not just unique to the cloud,
right?

00:07:17.400 --> 00:07:20.700
This is something that just is good
common best practice, good common sense.

00:07:20.700 --> 00:07:22.580
You would do it any
kind of infrastructure,

00:07:22.580 --> 00:07:24.500
whether it's cloud-based or not.

00:07:24.500 --> 00:07:26.500
You should be up to date
on your patch management.

00:07:26.500 --> 00:07:27.740
You should be doing
configuration management,

00:07:27.740 --> 00:07:29.960
you should be doing continuous monitoring.

00:07:29.960 --> 00:07:33.650
You should be locking down your hosts,
you should be using approved hardware

00:07:33.650 --> 00:07:37.200
with secure designs that are being
implemented and vetted, right?

00:07:37.200 --> 00:07:38.940
This is all just common
sense stuff you would do,

00:07:38.940 --> 00:07:40.580
whether we're in the cloud or not.

00:07:40.580 --> 00:07:44.140
But the point is that when we add
this thought process into the cloud,

00:07:44.140 --> 00:07:48.700
the cloud can become as secure as
all the other infrastructure we run,

00:07:48.700 --> 00:07:50.990
if we apply the same common sense
management perspectives and

00:07:50.990 --> 00:07:52.640
security approaches to it.

00:07:52.640 --> 00:07:54.354
So this is very important for
us to think about.

00:07:54.354 --> 00:07:57.937
While we differentiate the cloud, and
we say, yes, it's a different environment.

00:07:57.937 --> 00:07:59.652
It runs differently,
it's managed differently.

00:07:59.652 --> 00:08:01.974
Reality is, a lot of it is the same.

00:08:01.974 --> 00:08:03.721
But I've made this point time and again.

00:08:03.721 --> 00:08:06.437
But I want that point to continue for
something, for

00:08:06.437 --> 00:08:09.770
you to be able to hear that and
continue to have that continue to be

00:08:09.770 --> 00:08:14.340
something that you are thinking about
throughout our conversations together and

00:08:14.340 --> 00:08:17.521
throughout your time as you're not
only prepare to become a CCSP.

00:08:17.521 --> 00:08:21.194
But ultimately, out beyond that as you
are a CCSP at some point in the future and

00:08:21.194 --> 00:08:23.490
you're actually doing
cloud security worker.

00:08:23.490 --> 00:08:25.880
If you're doing it already and
you continue to do it,

00:08:25.880 --> 00:08:28.816
you have to bring that thought
process to work with you everyday.

00:08:28.816 --> 00:08:33.459
What am I gonna do to secure the cloud
is the question the CCSP asks.

00:08:33.459 --> 00:08:38.501
But the reality or the real take on
that question is not what am I gonna do

00:08:38.501 --> 00:08:44.570
that is necessarily cloud specific, but
what am I gonna do that is generic and

00:08:44.570 --> 00:08:47.237
that has to be tuned, applied, modified.

00:08:47.237 --> 00:08:50.863
And essentially, somehow constrained or
constricted to apply

00:08:50.863 --> 00:08:55.930
to the cloud if that's the unique
environment variable I have to address,

00:08:55.930 --> 00:08:57.594
but patch management is patch management.

00:08:57.594 --> 00:08:59.449
Log management is log management.

00:08:59.449 --> 00:09:00.909
Using configuration management,

00:09:00.909 --> 00:09:03.800
it's the same whether you
do it in the cloud or not.

00:09:03.800 --> 00:09:06.700
So, don't avoid those
common sense solutions.

00:09:06.700 --> 00:09:09.588
Don't avoid the things we know
are going to be impactful, useful and

00:09:09.588 --> 00:09:12.453
valuable in the toolkit of
the security professional.

00:09:12.453 --> 00:09:15.431
Make sure you embrace them,
bring them into the cloud, but

00:09:15.431 --> 00:09:18.948
then add the cloud's specific flavors
necessary to ensure success in

00:09:18.948 --> 00:09:22.423
the unique environments that we
find ourselves in within the cloud.

00:09:22.423 --> 00:09:25.813
>> Adam,
would you say that it's getting easier for

00:09:25.813 --> 00:09:30.900
us to be more security minded and
implement secure features,

00:09:30.900 --> 00:09:35.252
secure hardware and design, because we
are living, in which it seems to me,

00:09:35.252 --> 00:09:38.993
a secure centric or
securely idealized environment.

00:09:38.993 --> 00:09:41.705
Everything nowadays,
you get a laptop nowadays,

00:09:41.705 --> 00:09:44.739
it's more likely you are getting
one without a TPM in it.

00:09:44.739 --> 00:09:47.529
It's unlikely that there's
not going to be secure or

00:09:47.529 --> 00:09:50.629
security design elements inside
of software that you buy,

00:09:50.629 --> 00:09:54.422
they're gonna have patch management
that you will be able to update it.

00:09:54.422 --> 00:09:59.222
Is that making our job easier or are we
still seeing the fact that these things

00:09:59.222 --> 00:10:04.370
are not happening or you're still bound
to run across very insecure items?

00:10:04.370 --> 00:10:06.810
>> Sure.
So its a great question from a couple of

00:10:06.810 --> 00:10:10.390
perspectives, cuz we're
really thinking about ooh,

00:10:10.390 --> 00:10:13.760
I don't wanna quite call
it nurture versus nature.

00:10:13.760 --> 00:10:17.778
This age old argument about whether we
learn to do certain things or whether

00:10:17.778 --> 00:10:22.321
we're natively, naturally born to them and
they're part of our DNA essentially.

00:10:22.321 --> 00:10:25.592
They're intuitive and they're there
just because they're just part of being

00:10:25.592 --> 00:10:27.670
a human, regardless of what we do.

00:10:27.670 --> 00:10:27.902
I don't think it's quite that.

00:10:27.902 --> 00:10:30.810
Because clearly,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam talk about what it takes to run your physical infrastructure securely. They go over physical access security measures like secure KVMs. They also talk more about secure network configurations by using VLANs, TLS, DNS Sec, and firewalls. Finally they discuss physical segregation for stand-alone hosts and the availability of clustered hosts through DRS, Dynamic Optimization, and High Availability.

00:23:34.330 --> 00:23:39.280
the agenda prior, it walk through whatever

If they are approved they

00:23:41.290 --> 00:23:45.300
The change requests are and then at

everybody comes in, the appropriate

00:23:54.247 --> 00:23:58.023

00:24:01.372 --> 00:24:03.393

they do a presentation,

00:24:03.393 --> 00:24:05.706

00:24:05.706 --> 00:24:08.307
Different people with different

00:24:08.307 --> 00:24:13.262
At the end of the meeting,

00:24:13.262 --> 00:24:17.812

00:24:17.812 --> 00:24:21.110

00:24:21.110 --> 00:24:24.034

this change is not good,

00:24:24.034 --> 00:24:25.750

00:24:25.750 --> 00:24:28.440

00:24:28.440 --> 00:24:31.910

00:24:31.910 --> 00:24:35.070

00:24:35.070 --> 00:24:37.375

00:25:05.750 --> 00:25:07.720

00:25:15.170 --> 00:25:16.320

00:25:16.320 --> 00:25:19.890

00:25:19.890 --> 00:25:24.140
Sometimes called a lessons learned,

00:25:24.140 --> 00:25:25.260

00:25:25.260 --> 00:25:26.310

00:25:26.310 --> 00:25:29.713

00:25:29.713 --> 00:25:33.488

it's essentially referred to as a PIR more

501
00:25:33.488 --> 00:25:35.990
often than not,
a post-implementation review.

502
00:25:35.990 --> 00:25:38.180
And the idea is that we do
a lessons learned, right?

503
00:25:38.180 --> 00:25:39.350
We go through and look at what worked.

504
00:25:39.350 --> 00:25:42.250
Well hey,

00:25:42.250 --> 00:25:44.550

all the testing was done,

00:25:44.550 --> 00:25:46.090

00:25:46.090 --> 00:25:48.040
Check, check, check, good,

Or, wow, blew up, right,

00:26:13.157 --> 00:26:17.393

00:26:17.393 --> 00:26:21.972

One that rises above the level

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss the process and concepts of Risk Assessment. They start by defining risk which leads them to looking at defined ways of framing risk. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take you through the process of collecting and preserving of evidence in the case of a data breach incident. They explain the proper methods of collecting data and then detail the proper way that evidence should be handled. They also explore the different parties and stakeholders that need to be notified and informed during this time.
