00:17:46.370 --> 00:17:49.030
coordinating it,
making sure we have an evidence log, and

363
00:17:49.030 --> 00:17:51.900
then safely transporting that
evidence back into storage.

364
00:17:51.900 --> 00:17:52.605
And ultimately then,

365
00:17:52.605 --> 00:17:56.418
is gonna be responsible for bringing that
evidence in under the proper conditions.

366
00:17:56.418 --> 00:17:58.053
Not throwing it into
the back of your car in

367
00:17:58.053 --> 00:17:58.960
the trunk,
>> [LAUGH]

368
00:17:58.960 --> 00:17:59.930
>> Riding around with it for

369
00:17:59.930 --> 00:18:02.380
a week or two, and then remembering,
I gotta bring that in and

370
00:18:02.380 --> 00:18:04.660
probably sign that in to
the evidence locker, right?

371
00:18:04.660 --> 00:18:07.577
After we've banged that hard drive
around and bake it for a week or more.

372
00:18:07.577 --> 00:18:08.308
>> Covered in cheeseburger grease.

373
00:18:08.308 --> 00:18:09.527
>> Cuz there'll be a lot of good
stuff on there at that point, right?

374
00:18:09.527 --> 00:18:10.224
>> Yeah, awesome.

375
00:18:10.224 --> 00:18:11.305
[LAUGH]
>> Absolutely, right.

376
00:18:11.305 --> 00:18:12.803
So, we have to think about all that,
that's gonna be important.

377
00:18:12.803 --> 00:18:15.146
We have to analyze,
examine the data, right?

378
00:18:15.146 --> 00:18:17.035
We gotta know what's going on there.

379
00:18:17.035 --> 00:18:19.850
We gotta have trained professionals
that are gonna do this.

380
00:18:19.850 --> 00:18:22.280
How do we create a forensically
sound report of that evidence?

381
00:18:22.280 --> 00:18:25.355
Well, we've gotta detail out what
we found under certain conditions.

382
00:18:25.355 --> 00:18:28.272
We gotta think about the audience
that we're reporting to.

383
00:18:28.272 --> 00:18:31.208
We've talked about audience reliability
and audience relevancy before.

384
00:18:31.208 --> 00:18:34.442
We’ve talked about actionable information,
alternative explanations for

385
00:18:34.442 --> 00:18:35.520
what we're seeing.

386
00:18:35.520 --> 00:18:37.110
We gotta think about all this stuff.

387
00:18:37.110 --> 00:18:39.070
What about the host
operating system itself?

388
00:18:39.070 --> 00:18:41.440
Remember, if we're in the cloud and
we're virtualizing,

389
00:18:41.440 --> 00:18:42.810
we've got two operating systems.

390
00:18:42.810 --> 00:18:44.720
We've got a host and then we have one or

391
00:18:44.720 --> 00:18:48.350
more guest operating systems that
are probably running very different OSs.

392
00:18:48.350 --> 00:18:51.550
Different interpretations of data,
different configurations,

393
00:18:51.550 --> 00:18:55.108
we got to deal with both when we deal
with forensic examinations in the cloud.

394
00:18:55.108 --> 00:18:57.310
So this is also very important.

395
00:18:57.310 --> 00:19:01.350
Physical access is gonna be required for
the host to gather operating system-based

396
00:19:01.350 --> 00:19:05.445
data, and to do data a gathering,
as opposed to logical access,

397
00:19:05.445 --> 00:19:08.990
remotely gathering information
from the running VM on the host.

398
00:19:08.990 --> 00:19:10.180
So we have to think about that.

399
00:19:10.180 --> 00:19:13.720
We need a write blocker as we said,
to be used to gather this data.

400
00:19:13.720 --> 00:19:16.460
What about the guest operating system,
the VM access, or

401
00:19:16.460 --> 00:19:18.500
the VM operating system
running on top of this?

402
00:19:18.500 --> 00:19:20.050
We have to think about this as well.

403
00:19:20.050 --> 00:19:23.360
Snapshotting may be the best method
to deal with collecting forensic

404
00:19:23.360 --> 00:19:26.390
examinational, or, forensic examinational,

405
00:19:26.390 --> 00:19:29.462
boy I'm just making up English
words as we go here left and right.

406
00:19:29.462 --> 00:19:30.330
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

407
00:19:30.330 --> 00:19:31.826
>> Forensically sound information, and

408
00:19:31.826 --> 00:19:32.360
to examine it.

409
00:19:32.360 --> 00:19:36.545
So taking a snapshot, freezing the state
of that machine at a moment in time,

410
00:19:36.545 --> 00:19:40.150
timestamping it, using a write
blocker to prevent write back, and

411
00:19:40.150 --> 00:19:44.870
then hashing it, would be the appropriate
and proper method of capturing

412
00:19:44.870 --> 00:19:49.580
a forensically sound image from
a running VM on top of a host.

413
00:19:49.580 --> 00:19:52.490
We may snapshot it and
we may have to use software to do that.

414
00:19:52.490 --> 00:19:54.960
So again, write blockers should
be put in place to do that.

415
00:19:54.960 --> 00:19:55.860
What about metadata?

416
00:19:55.860 --> 00:19:57.650
Scraping all of the data out of a system,

417
00:19:57.650 --> 00:20:00.130
will leave behind the data
that describes the data.

418
00:20:00.130 --> 00:20:02.900
We have to think about metadata and
its value as well.

419
00:20:02.900 --> 00:20:04.380
And we may wanna understand, or

420
00:20:04.380 --> 00:20:08.820
not may, we should understand that
metadata is equally important here, right?

421
00:20:08.820 --> 00:20:11.850
So we have to understand that
the data that describes the data,

422
00:20:11.850 --> 00:20:14.580
may have information that may
be forensically valuable.

423
00:20:14.580 --> 00:20:17.342
Chain of custody as we've talked about,
very, very important.

424
00:20:17.342 --> 00:20:20.190
We gotta make sure that we treat
the digital evidence identical

425
00:20:20.190 --> 00:20:22.410
to physical evidence,
when it comes to chain of custody.

426
00:20:22.410 --> 00:20:23.900
It should be handled the same way.

427
00:20:23.900 --> 00:20:26.420
We have to be able to prove that
that evidence was secure and

428
00:20:26.420 --> 00:20:29.440
under the control of
a particular party at all times.

429
00:20:29.440 --> 00:20:32.520
This ultimately is probably
the most important thing.

430
00:20:32.520 --> 00:20:36.040
And this is the pivot point that court
cases get decided on all the time.

431
00:20:36.040 --> 00:20:40.220
If we screw up the evidence and screw up
the handling and we cannot introduce that

432
00:20:40.220 --> 00:20:44.540
evidence, then it may very well be the
difference between guilt and innocence.

433
00:20:44.540 --> 00:20:47.040
Not to harp on this one case by any means,
but

434
00:20:47.040 --> 00:20:50.920
if you think about in the United States,
many, many years ago,

435
00:20:50.920 --> 00:20:53.010
you think about the O.J.
Simpson trial, right?

436
00:20:53.010 --> 00:20:55.770
Whether you think O.J. Simpson was
guilty or innocent, irrelevant,

437
00:20:55.770 --> 00:20:59.250
not gonna have that conversation,
don't care, not interested in knowing.

438
00:20:59.250 --> 00:21:03.550
I'm just pointing out that the thing,
ultimately, that led to O.J. Simpson being

439
00:21:03.550 --> 00:21:07.620
found innocent, right, in the criminal
trial, but guilty in the civil trial,

440
00:21:07.620 --> 00:21:11.670
was the fact that the evidence and
the chain of custody of that evidence, and

441
00:21:11.670 --> 00:21:15.650
the handling of it by various parties,
was called into question.

442
00:21:15.650 --> 00:21:19.490
And there was enough reasonable doubt
created in the mind of the jury, and

443
00:21:19.490 --> 00:21:22.095
in the mind of the judge,
that on the criminal side,

444
00:21:22.095 --> 00:21:26.420
in the criminal trial about whether he
actually did or did not commit that act,

445
00:21:26.420 --> 00:21:30.990
that evidence was not able to be used
conclusively to find him guilty, right?

446
00:21:30.990 --> 00:21:32.920
But yet
in the civil trial he was found guilty.

447
00:21:32.920 --> 00:21:34.032
So it's kind of interesting, right?

448
00:21:34.032 --> 00:21:36.801
In theory he didn't commit a crime, but
yet he was found that he had to pay for

449
00:21:36.801 --> 00:21:37.753
a crime he did not commit,

450
00:21:37.753 --> 00:21:40.457
which is the beautiful thing about
the American justice system, right?

451
00:21:40.457 --> 00:21:44.387
[LAUGH] So we just wanna understand that,
but just know that sometimes this can

452
00:21:44.387 --> 00:21:48.390
happen, and it is not unusual if
evidence is not handled correctly.

453
00:21:48.390 --> 00:21:53.175
A nota bene, nota bene,
which is Latin, n-o-t-a b-e-n-e, or

454
00:21:53.175 --> 00:21:56.117
notabeeny as one of my students once said.

455
00:21:56.117 --> 00:21:56.625
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

456
00:21:56.625 --> 00:21:57.489
>> Right, nota bene,

457
00:21:57.489 --> 00:22:00.805
essentially digital evidence has
two parts, the physical medium and

458
00:22:00.805 --> 00:22:02.755
the information itself, right?

459
00:22:02.755 --> 00:22:07.085
And so we need to understand the concept
of nota bene, is that the evidence,

460
00:22:07.085 --> 00:22:11.360
right, and the information,
the physical medium it's contained in and

461
00:22:11.360 --> 00:22:14.330
the information itself,
both make up the evidence.

462
00:22:14.330 --> 00:22:15.730
And those two parts together,

463
00:22:15.730 --> 00:22:18.150
we need chain of custody
associated with both of them.

464
00:22:18.150 --> 00:22:20.510
So we wanna understand the concept,
that it’s a legal term,

465
00:22:20.510 --> 00:22:22.510
and the concept associated with it.

466
00:22:22.510 --> 00:22:24.460
Evidence management is critical.

467
00:22:24.460 --> 00:22:27.780
And chain of custody of
the evidence is critical for

468
00:22:27.780 --> 00:22:30.280
our ability to be able to
be successful in this area.

469
00:22:30.280 --> 00:22:32.890
We also need to think a little bit
about vendors and partners, and

470
00:22:32.890 --> 00:22:34.600
how we reach out and deal with them.

471
00:22:34.600 --> 00:22:38.240
We've talked about this before,
managing supply chain risk.

472
00:22:38.240 --> 00:22:40.903
And understanding how to deal
with vendors through federation.

473
00:22:40.903 --> 00:22:44.072
And contracting with them
to consume cloud services.

474
00:22:44.072 --> 00:22:47.519
And we have to also think about the fact
that we have to be very up front and

475
00:22:47.519 --> 00:22:51.483
very specific about our needs and our
desires in that contractual obligation, or

476
00:22:51.483 --> 00:22:53.450
in that contractual agreement rather.

477
00:22:53.450 --> 00:22:55.750
We have to make sure that we
understand how to use due care and

478
00:22:55.750 --> 00:22:59.250
due diligence to our advantage to get
what we want from our cloud vendors.

479
00:22:59.250 --> 00:23:02.480
So we often think about the idea
of on-boarding of vendors.

480
00:23:02.480 --> 00:23:05.330
How do we interact with them and
get them into our ecosystem?

481
00:23:05.330 --> 00:23:06.250
How do we manage them?

482
00:23:06.250 --> 00:23:08.382
How do we deal with them while
we're doing business with them?

483
00:23:08.382 --> 00:23:09.334
And how do we off board them, right?

484
00:23:09.334 --> 00:23:13.255
How do we do business with them, associate
with them, but ultimately over time, exit?

485
00:23:13.255 --> 00:23:16.135
And we need to have clearly
defined exit strategies, and

486
00:23:16.135 --> 00:23:18.475
clearly defined onboarding strategies, and

487
00:23:18.475 --> 00:23:23.100
clearly defined management strategies at
all phases of the vendor relationship.

488
00:23:23.100 --> 00:23:25.650
We also need to remember that
ultimately the guiding principle, and

489
00:23:25.650 --> 00:23:28.160
the guiding documentation element here,
for the CCSP,

490
00:23:28.160 --> 00:23:31.170
is the SLA,
the service level agreement, right?

491
00:23:31.170 --> 00:23:34.890
That's where all of the expectations and
stipulations about service will be found.

492
00:23:34.890 --> 00:23:37.521
And we need to understand how
to use that to our advantage.

493
00:23:37.521 --> 00:23:41.999
It must detail out for
us what the expectations of service are,

494
00:23:41.999 --> 00:23:45.733
remember 596979 up time, seconds, right?

495
00:23:45.733 --> 00:23:46.476
>> Yeah.

496
00:23:46.476 --> 00:23:47.544
>> Tenths, hundredths of seconds, right?

497
00:23:47.544 --> 00:23:48.763
>> Microseconds.
>> Microseconds.

498
00:23:48.763 --> 00:23:50.870
We have to have all that and
know that, right?

499
00:23:50.870 --> 00:23:55.000
And we have to make sure that we're
constantly realigning our expectations,

500
00:23:55.000 --> 00:23:57.930
not just for ourselves in the business,
but also remember,

501
00:23:57.930 --> 00:24:00.600
regulatory compliance concerns
have to be represented and

502
00:24:00.600 --> 00:24:04.208
maintained in the SLA, as do
stakeholder requirements and concerns.

503
00:24:04.208 --> 00:24:07.890
There's multiple parties that the CCSP,
in other words, has to play to and

504
00:24:07.890 --> 00:24:10.590
understand how to interact with,
with regards to this.

505
00:24:10.590 --> 00:24:14.380
And all of this information, all these
various feeder elements have to be

506
00:24:14.380 --> 00:24:18.480
distilled down translated, and hopefully
managed against the expectations.

507
00:24:18.480 --> 00:24:21.160
And when necessary,
realigning the expectations

508
00:24:21.160 --> 00:24:24.350
to meet them is gonna be part
of our job as CCSPs as well.

509
00:24:24.350 --> 00:24:25.390
It's gonna be very important.

510
00:24:25.390 --> 00:24:27.600
>> Well Adam, this is definitely,
as far as I'm concerned,

511
00:24:27.600 --> 00:24:29.220
we saved the best for last.

512
00:24:29.220 --> 00:24:33.334
One of the coolest things to talk about
is what happens if something actually

513
00:24:33.334 --> 00:24:34.696
happens, what do we do?

514
00:24:34.696 --> 00:24:35.915
And this is what it's all about, right?

515
00:24:35.915 --> 00:24:40.632
The forensic evidence, gathering that
stuff up, examining it, making sure

516
00:24:40.632 --> 00:24:45.134
that its integrity is maintained, and
then ultimately being used to maybe

517
00:24:45.134 --> 00:24:50.080
uncover the culpable parties, or just
figuring out what the heck went wrong.

518
00:24:50.080 --> 00:24:53.050
That just might be the thing of it,
you never know.

519
00:24:53.050 --> 00:24:54.310
It may just look like a breach, but

520
00:24:54.310 --> 00:24:57.610
it was really that Adam spilled
an espresso on the server.

521
00:24:57.610 --> 00:24:58.910
And blew it up accidentally.

522
00:24:58.910 --> 00:24:59.675
>> I'm just covering.

523
00:24:59.675 --> 00:25:01.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm just lying outright,

524
00:25:01.560 --> 00:25:02.890
I'm just not saying that I did it.

525
00:25:02.890 --> 00:25:03.510
I'm-
>> Exactly.

526
00:25:03.510 --> 00:25:04.230
>> Culpable for nothing.

527
00:25:04.230 --> 00:25:04.780
>> That's right.

528
00:25:04.780 --> 00:25:05.860
>> I'm culpable for nothing.

529
00:25:05.860 --> 00:25:10.385
>> But definitely, I would say
the sexiest part of being in security,

530
00:25:10.385 --> 00:25:15.095
is being a part of the forensic
gathering and examination portion.

531
00:25:15.095 --> 00:25:15.860
>> It is a cool part.

532
00:25:15.860 --> 00:25:16.800
>> Very cool stuff.

533
00:25:16.800 --> 00:25:18.120
>> It is a cool part, no doubt about it.

534
00:25:18.120 --> 00:25:21.410
>> Adam, we have trudged a long and
arduous journey, but

535
00:25:21.410 --> 00:25:23.680
it looks like we have come to the end.

536
00:25:23.680 --> 00:25:25.120
I do thank you so much, Sir.

537
00:25:25.120 --> 00:25:25.670
>> You're welcome.

538
00:25:25.670 --> 00:25:26.745
>> Your kung fu is strong.

539
00:25:26.745 --> 00:25:28.820
>> [LAUGH]
>> And hopefully ours will be stronger for

540
00:25:28.820 --> 00:25:30.180
having been around it.

541
00:25:30.180 --> 00:25:33.040
That being said,
we are signing off for ITPro.TV.

542
00:25:33.040 --> 00:25:34.933
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

543
00:25:34.933 --> 00:25:36.348
>> I have been your host, Adam Gordon.

544
00:25:36.348 --> 00:25:37.370
>> And we'll see you next time.

545

And the things that we as CCSP's

00:01:22.890 --> 00:01:26.880

generically driving down the street

00:01:52.677 --> 00:01:56.632
There are so many, if you stop and think,

00:01:59.974 --> 00:02:04.740
countries there are many, many laws that

So for instance, universally

somebody with a gun holding the gun
at you or a red flag or something,

00:29:46.550 --> 00:29:49.280
We address all of these ideas,
all of these concerns,

568
00:29:49.280 --> 00:29:53.430
all of these areas with the negotiated
agreement between the two parties.

569
00:29:53.430 --> 00:29:56.950
We've talked about the fact that Safe
Harbor, at least between the United States

570
00:29:56.950 --> 00:30:01.420
and the EU at the time of our
discussions here now in the present, and

571
00:30:01.420 --> 00:30:05.860
back to late 2015,
has kind of been turned upside down

572
00:30:05.860 --> 00:30:08.730
from the perspective of preparing for
an exam like this.

573
00:30:08.730 --> 00:30:10.730
You have to understand two things.

574
00:30:10.730 --> 00:30:13.990
Number one, the exam was written and
produced initially, and

575
00:30:13.990 --> 00:30:18.990
the questions that most likely were
produced initially, were written at a time

576
00:30:18.990 --> 00:30:22.140
when Safe Harbor was still in
effect between the US and the EU.

577
00:30:22.140 --> 00:30:25.940
I'm not telling you anything that you
should not know because the exam questions

578
00:30:25.940 --> 00:30:28.000
were written prior to
the release of the exam.

579
00:30:28.000 --> 00:30:33.870
And the credential went
live in mid to late 2015.

580
00:30:33.870 --> 00:30:37.820
But as a result of that you need to
know that that material would have

581
00:30:37.820 --> 00:30:42.360
been produced initially prior to
the issues of the concerns that led to

582
00:30:42.360 --> 00:30:46.650
the effective breaking of the Safe Harbor
accord between the US and the EU.

583
00:30:47.650 --> 00:30:50.530
The exam at some point may very
well be updated with new questions

584
00:30:50.530 --> 00:30:54.430
that will reflect the current state of
the Safe Harbor accord and the shift to

585
00:30:54.430 --> 00:30:58.870
this idea of Privacy Shield, but that is
unclear as to when that would happen.

586
00:30:58.870 --> 00:31:01.720
It's unclear as to whether it will,
and if it will when and

587
00:31:01.720 --> 00:31:03.250
what you would need to know.

588
00:31:03.250 --> 00:31:05.830
So I would say generically
it would be very helpful for

589
00:31:05.830 --> 00:31:10.530
you to be aware of what the concept of
Safe Harbor is, the guiding principles,

590
00:31:10.530 --> 00:31:13.940
and the reasons why we may
negotiate a Safe Harbor agreement.

591
00:31:13.940 --> 00:31:17.290
Would I spend a lot of time
understanding the specificity

592
00:31:17.290 --> 00:31:20.920
of the US EU Safe Harbor agreement
that's no longer in force?

593
00:31:20.920 --> 00:31:22.080
No, I really wouldn't.

594
00:31:22.080 --> 00:31:25.810
What I would do, is understand the concept
of why we would've had a Safe Harbor

595
00:31:25.810 --> 00:31:29.660
agreement in the first place and what
the guiding principles are, or would be.

596
00:31:29.660 --> 00:31:34.008
And if you have those and you understand
those, you're gonna be well positioned to

597
00:31:34.008 --> 00:31:38.845
answer any kind of question, that comes up
with regards to a Safe Harbor alternative.

598
00:31:38.845 --> 00:31:41.665
So you wanna make sure you have
a sense of that and understand that.

599
00:31:41.665 --> 00:31:42.710
If that is helpful and

600
00:31:42.710 --> 00:31:46.495
indeed gives you a point of reference,a
little context if you will.

601
00:31:46.495 --> 00:31:49.410
Just wanna make sure we are aware of
that and we have a sense of that also.

602
00:31:49.410 --> 00:31:53.485
>> [SOUND] Adam, obviously we are living
in a world where just because.

603
00:31:53.485 --> 00:31:54.309
>> Livin la vida loca.

604
00:31:54.309 --> 00:31:56.175
>> Yeah, we are livin la vida loca.

605
00:31:56.175 --> 00:32:02.220
But again, it goes back to the idea
that our cloud environment is global.

606
00:32:02.220 --> 00:32:05.810
It goes everywhere, and therefore we
have to be able to work inside of

607
00:32:05.810 --> 00:32:09.020
that environment, and remember that
there are laws that govern them,

608
00:32:09.020 --> 00:32:13.450
depending on where you are at or where
your data might be at, at any given time.

609
00:32:13.450 --> 00:32:16.740
So that being said we have to take
a close look at these things.

610
00:32:16.740 --> 00:32:20.730
And get a good familiarization with
that because as you become a CCSP and

611
00:32:20.730 --> 00:32:26.230
as Adam has pointed out, you are going to
be expected to be able to intelligently

612
00:32:26.230 --> 00:32:29.600
speak about these things, understand
the concepts and deal with them.

613
00:32:29.600 --> 00:32:33.970
And come up with a design and a philosophy
in your environment that is going to suit

614
00:32:33.970 --> 00:32:36.500
what your business model
is at that point in time.

615
00:32:36.500 --> 00:32:37.830
Adam, we thank you so much for

616
00:32:37.830 --> 00:32:41.080
explaining these concepts to us even
though they can be a bit daunting.

617
00:32:41.080 --> 00:32:44.340
You have been a great and
tremendous help for this on that.

618
00:32:44.340 --> 00:32:46.040
We do thank you guys for joining us today.

619
00:32:46.040 --> 00:32:47.520
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

620
00:32:47.520 --> 00:32:50.050
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

621
00:32:50.050 --> 00:32:50.770
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

622
00:32:50.770 --> 00:32:52.915
>> And we'll see you next time.

623
00:32:52.915 --> 00:32:58.673

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam examine the audit process for cloud-based systems. They start by differentiating between internal and external audits. Then they talk about assurance challenges of Cloud systems. Finally, they walk you through the different types of audit reports, restrictions, and gap analysis.
episodes.title: Cloud Audit Processes

about legal concerns, ramifications,

26
00:00:48.460 --> 00:00:51.130
issues that we have to

27
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:54.830
We're going to do a little but of a focus
here on audit and cloud audit processes.

28
00:00:54.830 --> 00:00:56.230
What are the methodologies,

29
00:00:56.230 --> 00:00:59.470
the things that we have to be concerned
with regards to the cloud environment.

30
00:00:59.470 --> 00:01:02.420
You know when we think about audits
we think of the idea of either being

31
00:01:02.420 --> 00:01:05.380
able internally in some cases or
externally in others,

32

or perhaps both over the course

33
00:01:08.150 --> 00:01:11.395
To examine what our expectations are and

34
00:01:11.395 --> 00:01:15.425
see whether what we think is happening
is actually in truth happening.

35
00:01:15.425 --> 00:01:16.885
So we're inspecting,

36

in other words, to assess whether what
we've been told is the case really is.

37
00:01:21.135 --> 00:01:24.165
And so when we start out from that
perspective with regards to an audit,

38
00:01:24.165 --> 00:01:27.115
we have to understand that there
are rules that we follow with regards

39
00:01:27.115 --> 00:01:27.955
to doing audits.

40
00:01:27.955 --> 00:01:29.215
We have a process.

41
00:01:29.215 --> 00:01:30.205
We have procedures.

42
00:01:30.205 --> 00:01:31.265
We have thing we will or

43
00:01:31.265 --> 00:01:34.650
will not be able to do based on
the kind of audit we're engaging in.

44
00:01:34.650 --> 00:01:36.390
But ultimately, we're going to,

45
00:01:36.390 --> 00:01:41.070
if we do this the right way,
engage in internal audits to help us,

46
00:01:41.070 --> 00:01:45.570
number one, validate and verify,
the extent of our protection mechanisms.

47
00:01:45.570 --> 00:01:48.110
Validate and verify that they
are operating the way they should.

48
00:01:48.110 --> 00:01:50.260
And then to prepare us for

49
00:01:50.260 --> 00:01:54.370
an external audit, somebody who's
impartial, outside the organization.

50
00:01:54.370 --> 00:01:57.310
Who's gonna come in,
at least once a year typically.

51
00:01:57.310 --> 00:02:01.480
And is then going to go through and
probably engage in very similar steps and

52
00:02:01.480 --> 00:02:04.070
similar exercises to what
we've done internally.

53
00:02:04.070 --> 00:02:08.870
But as a result of doing that from an
external perspective, provide an unbiased

54
00:02:08.870 --> 00:02:13.330
and relatively accurate assessment and
accounting of what is indeed going on.

55
00:02:13.330 --> 00:02:17.710
And we could then take that, we could show
that to our customers, we could provide

56
00:02:17.710 --> 00:02:21.930
a letter of attestation as a result of the
outcome of the audit if it is positive.

57
00:02:21.930 --> 00:02:25.260
And if it is favorable to us,
and we can show our customers,

58
00:02:25.260 --> 00:02:28.920
if we are the cloud provider,
that we are meeting the obligations.

59
00:02:28.920 --> 00:02:32.700
Enforcing the security requirements
that we are expected to do in

60
00:02:32.700 --> 00:02:34.280
order to provide protections.

61
00:02:34.280 --> 00:02:38.460
And we can then assure them,
with reasonableness, that their data and

62
00:02:38.460 --> 00:02:41.690
indeed, all the things that they do on
our platform, are going to be safe and

63
00:02:41.690 --> 00:02:45.030
secure for another year or
whatever the timeline is.

64
00:02:45.030 --> 00:02:47.830
Now we also have to understand
that the audit is essentially

65
00:02:47.830 --> 00:02:49.820
a frozen snapshot moment in time.

66
00:02:49.820 --> 00:02:53.050
At the moment we check,
the results are valid.

67
00:02:53.050 --> 00:02:56.750
Six months from then, the results may not
be valid, because things may have changed,

68
00:02:56.750 --> 00:03:00.870
unless we're auditing continuously, unless
we have a constant validation of that.

69
00:03:00.870 --> 00:03:04.390
We only know that the moment in time we
were good, but that doesn't necessarily

70
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:08.600
work into the future, nor by the way
does it work backwards into the past.

71
00:03:08.600 --> 00:03:11.140
It is simply,
literally a frozen moment in time,

72
00:03:11.140 --> 00:03:15.410
a snapshot of the current state of
the governance and the compliance

73
00:03:15.410 --> 00:03:19.900
of the organization at the moment we show
up and essentially decide we wanna check.

74
00:03:19.900 --> 00:03:22.280
But that doesn't necessarily
mean that it will or

75
00:03:22.280 --> 00:03:24.100
will not be compliant in the future.

76
00:03:24.100 --> 00:03:25.910
I'm not suggesting that
it means it won't be.

77
00:03:25.910 --> 00:03:27.680
But I'm also not promising
that it will be.

78
00:03:27.680 --> 00:03:31.760
Is essentially what the auditor says to
you when they give you the audit findings.

79
00:03:31.760 --> 00:03:33.910
So we do want to be aware of that.

80
00:03:33.910 --> 00:03:38.500
We tend to use the outcomes of
an audit as not only fodder for

81
00:03:38.500 --> 00:03:40.340
customers in terms of attestation.

82
00:03:40.340 --> 00:03:43.000
But usually internally we
submit that to our board,

83
00:03:43.000 --> 00:03:46.810
if there is a board of directors or
senior managers or stakeholders.

84
00:03:46.810 --> 00:03:48.540
Depending on the nature of the company,
but

85
00:03:48.540 --> 00:03:50.700
that's gonna help us to
understand what we're doing.

86
00:03:50.700 --> 00:03:54.650
Helps us to deal with the statements of
adjuration around risks that a board of

87
00:03:54.650 --> 00:03:58.480
directors may want, or that stake holders
may want to ensure that we're following

88
00:03:58.480 --> 00:04:02.670
proper financial management practices,
proper security practices.

89
00:04:02.670 --> 00:04:06.830
We are compliant with all the regulatory
requirements we may in our industry.

90
00:04:06.830 --> 00:04:09.590
These are all very important things,
right, when you think about it.

91
00:04:09.590 --> 00:04:12.450
So this is the kind of thing,
that audits can do for us.

92
00:04:12.450 --> 00:04:15.470
And we wanna start out our discussions,
by understanding that.

93
00:04:15.470 --> 00:04:18.970
Because, the thing with an audit in
the cloud, is that we have to again,

94
00:04:18.970 --> 00:04:23.590
as we've talked about in prior episodes,
make sure we have the right, to audit,

95
00:04:23.590 --> 00:04:24.630
as a customer.

96
00:04:24.630 --> 00:04:27.370
And if we don't have the right to
audit built into out contracts,

97
00:04:27.370 --> 00:04:31.140
we may actually find, unfortunately,
that we're not given access, and

98
00:04:31.140 --> 00:04:33.590
therefore not given the ability
to be able to audit.

99
00:04:33.590 --> 00:04:38.270
And I'm not suggesting that we're gonna
show up on the doorstep of the data center

100
00:04:38.270 --> 00:04:41.130
and demand from our Cloud provider that
we have a right to come in and audit.

101
00:04:41.130 --> 00:04:43.160
That's not how right to audit works and

102
00:04:43.160 --> 00:04:45.680
that's not typically what
right to audit implies.

103
00:04:45.680 --> 00:04:48.660
It implies that we have the right
to request from the Cloud provider

104
00:04:48.660 --> 00:04:52.520
Attestation that they have done an audit,
and then as a result of that, we could see

105
00:04:52.520 --> 00:04:56.480
the results of that at certain points
in time over the course of a year.

106
00:04:56.480 --> 00:04:58.850
But we're not necessarily
gonna be able to show up and

107
00:04:58.850 --> 00:05:01.930
conduct an on site audit ourselves,
that is very unlikely.

108
00:05:01.930 --> 00:05:05.570
There are scenarios where that may occur,
there are scenarios where that may be

109
00:05:05.570 --> 00:05:10.500
acceptable, there are scenarios where that
may be driven by a legal requirement.

110
00:05:10.500 --> 00:05:14.580
But those are well documented,
those are stipulated ahead of time and

111
00:05:14.580 --> 00:05:18.920
or come up in the due course of
a investigation, or something like that.

112
00:05:18.920 --> 00:05:23.670
And they are handled as one of exceptions
the standing rule in those cases with data

113
00:05:23.670 --> 00:05:27.070
centers is that you don't have a right
to show up and audit as an individual.

114
00:05:27.070 --> 00:05:30.040
Customers certainly not as
a retail client, not working for

115
00:05:30.040 --> 00:05:32.290
a major business You
could forget about that.

116
00:05:32.290 --> 00:05:35.370
If you're hosting on Office
365 as a person, and

117
00:05:35.370 --> 00:05:38.930
you're on Outlook.com,
using Hotmail or whatever,

118
00:05:38.930 --> 00:05:42.910
you have no right to go audit Microsoft
and request that they show you anything.

119
00:05:42.910 --> 00:05:45.800
For your $10 a month they're not
interested in talking to you.

120
00:05:45.800 --> 00:05:49.510
With regards to that, you can read
up on what they do provide, and

121
00:05:49.510 --> 00:05:52.170
the attestations of protection they offer.

122
00:05:52.170 --> 00:05:55.320
And you can use those to assure
yourself that you are hopefully

123
00:05:55.320 --> 00:05:57.420
having the right protection
supplied to your data, but

124
00:05:57.420 --> 00:06:00.960
that's about the extent of your right to
anything with regards to hosting there.

125
00:06:00.960 --> 00:06:03.970
It's only really when we talk
about businesses, right?

126
00:06:03.970 --> 00:06:05.090
In the enterprise space,

127
00:06:05.090 --> 00:06:08.000
that we start to really define
a right to audit beyond that.

128
00:06:08.000 --> 00:06:11.580
Now, keep in mind that if we
are doing private on-prem Cloud, so

129
00:06:11.580 --> 00:06:16.480
we are essentially the provider of Cloud's
services is IT to the business, right?

130
00:06:16.480 --> 00:06:18.800
And everything is internal, we own it all.

131
00:06:18.800 --> 00:06:21.540
The right to audit is essentially
the right to examine our own system.

132
00:06:21.540 --> 00:06:27.560
So we certainly have a right to audit in
certain well-defined cases in the cloud.

133
00:06:27.560 --> 00:06:31.277
But short of on-prem private cloud,
that right to audit may be very,

134
00:06:31.277 --> 00:06:33.867
very questionable and
may look very different.

135
00:06:33.867 --> 00:06:38.077
Depending on the requirements and the
pre-negotiation that we've engaged in, or

136
00:06:38.077 --> 00:06:41.115
the agreements that we have
a place with our cloud provider.

137
00:06:41.115 --> 00:06:42.824
Very important to think about that.

138
00:06:42.824 --> 00:06:45.026
Again, planning ahead right, look ahead.

139
00:06:45.026 --> 00:06:47.430
You're going to sign a contract for
at least a year,

140
00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:49.016
at least 12 months typically for

141
00:06:49.016 --> 00:06:53.008
cloud services maybe longer most companies
aren't going to really want to do business

142
00:06:53.008 --> 00:06:57.125
with you unless you're committing to at
least a 12 month run on their platform.

143
00:06:57.125 --> 00:06:59.355
So for the next 12 months,
if you're gonna commit,

144
00:06:59.355 --> 00:07:02.795
you gotta know ahead of time that you're
gonna need through at least one audit cuz

145
00:07:02.795 --> 00:07:06.010
you have a yearly standing policy
that says you audit every year.

146
00:07:06.010 --> 00:07:08.610
You know you've got to have at least
one during the next twelve months.

147
00:07:08.610 --> 00:07:12.500
You better make sure you work with that
cloud vendor to stipulate that's the case,

148
00:07:12.500 --> 00:07:15.570
and find out what is acceptable from
their perspective, and whether or

149
00:07:15.570 --> 00:07:19.410
not your traditional third party
audits gonna happen the same way.

150
00:07:19.410 --> 00:07:24.340
Or you're going to hand an attestation
to an auditor and say here you go.

151
00:07:24.340 --> 00:07:27.780
Tell us what else you want us to do,
cause that's all you're getting.

152
00:07:27.780 --> 00:07:28.990
And you gotta know that ahead of time.

153
00:07:28.990 --> 00:07:31.380
That's really, really critical for
you to be aware of.

154
00:07:31.380 --> 00:07:34.480
Present auditing methods,
as we talked about, in the real world

155
00:07:34.480 --> 00:07:39.500
may not work in the cloud outside of or
rather port it from the physical world.

156
00:07:39.500 --> 00:07:42.330
I said the real world like
the cloud is a mythical place that

157
00:07:42.330 --> 00:07:44.210
only exists in fairytales.

158
00:07:44.210 --> 00:07:47.650
So in the physical world outside of
the Cloud where we can walk up and

159
00:07:47.650 --> 00:07:49.270
actually audit systems directly.

160
00:07:49.270 --> 00:07:51.146
That doesn't happen in
the Cloud as we said.

161
00:07:51.146 --> 00:07:54.148
So we have to understand that
there are going to be changes,

162
00:07:54.148 --> 00:07:55.958
there are going to be constraints.

163
00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:59.969
We do need to know what those may be and
we have to assure ourselves of them, and

164
00:07:59.969 --> 00:08:01.810
document them ahead of time.

165
00:08:01.810 --> 00:08:04.156
We have assurance challenges
both in the cloud, but

166
00:08:04.156 --> 00:08:06.355
also with the platforms
that support the cloud.

167

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam contemplate the implications of Risk Management with regards to the Cloud. They assess the provider's risk and risk management as well as risk mitigation techniques. Then they go over many risk frameworks and metrics. Finally they discuss outsourcing and contract understanding/management.
episodes.title: Risk Management and Outsourcing

series.

Joining us back in the studio yet

7

11

killer from now on.

12

So everything's going well,
it's going well.

13

And we're here to talk a little bit more,
as we have been talking about in this area

14

15

I wanna talk about cloud from the
perspective of enterprise risk management,

16
00:00:51.210 --> 00:00:54.380
and from the perspective of
outsourcing and vendor relationships.

17
00:00:54.380 --> 00:00:57.720
And some of the odds and
ends that we still have to address here.

18
00:00:57.720 --> 00:01:02.130
We talked a lot about risk
across many of our shows and

19
00:01:02.130 --> 00:01:05.010
many of our episodes,
both in this area and in the CCSP.

20
00:01:05.010 --> 00:01:09.231
And more broadly, in many of the content
episodes you can watch here at ITProTV and

21
00:01:09.231 --> 00:01:11.140
many of the knowledge areas we have.

22
00:01:11.140 --> 00:01:16.110
Because risk is so pervasive, it's so
everywhere and all around us today so

23
00:01:16.110 --> 00:01:16.800
everywhere, right?

24
00:01:16.800 --> 00:01:19.550
That should be the new thing for
risk, risk it's so everywhere right?

25
00:01:19.550 --> 00:01:23.320
So risk is every where today we have to be
aware of that, we have to understand that

26
00:01:23.320 --> 00:01:26.220
and we have to think of what
we would consider risk to be.

27
00:01:26.220 --> 00:01:30.100
And also what we don't consider risk to be
to start to understand how to manage it.

28
00:01:30.100 --> 00:01:33.060
We've talked about the impact,
the importance, the need,

29
00:01:33.060 --> 00:01:37.050
in risk assessment for a BIA,
Business Impact Analysis.

30
00:01:37.050 --> 00:01:41.810
Why that can be and indeed is so important
to help us profile all the systems and

31
00:01:41.810 --> 00:01:43.710
services that we have, and

32
00:01:43.710 --> 00:01:46.120
then to understand their
importance to the organization.

33
00:01:46.120 --> 00:01:48.630
We talked about this in reference
to business continuity and

34
00:01:48.630 --> 00:01:51.780
disaster recovery planning for
instance in one of our prior discussions.

35
00:01:51.780 --> 00:01:56.050
And we have to think about the risk
profile of the organization, essentially

36
00:01:56.050 --> 00:01:59.470
the risk appetite which is often how
you hear risk profile referred to.

37
00:01:59.470 --> 00:02:03.830
How willing is the business to take on
certain risks, and under what conditions

38
00:02:03.830 --> 00:02:07.440
will those risks actually become important
for us to consider and/or to be aware of?

39
00:02:07.440 --> 00:02:09.870
And when we think about the risk profile,

40
00:02:09.870 --> 00:02:14.792
the risk profile should be set up in such
a way that risks are clearly identified.

41
00:02:14.792 --> 00:02:18.830
And ranked in some order so we understand
what risks we are taking on and

42
00:02:18.830 --> 00:02:20.920
what impact they may have to the business.

43
00:02:20.920 --> 00:02:23.790
And to that end, we wanna take
a look at the graphic that we have

44
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:26.340
on Daniel's machine with regards to risk.

45
00:02:26.340 --> 00:02:29.221
Or at least a nice little
interesting way I did set you up.

46
00:02:29.221 --> 00:02:30.389
[LAUGH].
I do apologize.

47
00:02:30.389 --> 00:02:34.290
I talked about showing I'm going through

49

I wanted to actually just throw this up

50
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:40.535
so surprise!

51
00:02:40.535 --> 00:02:41.460
[LAUGH].
Here we are.

52
00:02:41.460 --> 00:02:42.040
Here we are.

53
00:02:42.040 --> 00:02:44.830
[LAUGH] And so
let's talk a little bit about risk and

54
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:46.660
the risk matrix that
you see in front of us.

55
00:02:46.660 --> 00:02:49.075
This is a fairly traditional
way of representing risk.

56
00:02:49.075 --> 00:02:53.070
Danny and I were chatting right before
we got started and he looked at this and

57
00:02:53.070 --> 00:02:54.490
said, hey I've done that before.

58
00:02:54.490 --> 00:02:57.106
We do that in project management is
what you were telling me- Mm-hm.

59
00:02:57.106 --> 00:03:00.960
Right before we got started, and this is
a standardized way of looking at risk.

60
00:03:00.960 --> 00:03:03.490
Doesn't matter if we're
talking about cloud security.

61
00:03:03.490 --> 00:03:05.700
Doesn't matter if we're talking
about project management.

62
00:03:05.700 --> 00:03:07.270
As I said, risk is risk.

63
00:03:07.270 --> 00:03:11.430
We look at likelihood, which is on the
left hand column there, as you can see.

64
00:03:11.430 --> 00:03:17.780
We look at consequence or impact, which
is often how you hear consequence framed.

65
00:03:17.780 --> 00:03:22.150
And then as a result of likelihood and
consequence, we look at exposure.

66
00:03:22.150 --> 00:03:27.110
And exposure is what's gonna be the gray
shading that we see to represent likely,

67
00:03:27.110 --> 00:03:28.660
unlikely, highly unlikely.

68
00:03:28.660 --> 00:03:32.905
And then slightly harmful, harmful, and
extremely harmful, essentially modified,

69
00:03:32.905 --> 00:03:34.331
or excuse me, not modified.

70
00:03:34.331 --> 00:03:38.116
Multiplied together and added up in
such a way that we get a derivative and

71
00:03:38.116 --> 00:03:42.585
that derivative of green, yellow, and/or
red is going to be our exposure ranking or

72
00:03:42.585 --> 00:03:43.570
rating.

73
00:03:43.570 --> 00:03:47.040
So we have likelihood,
we have consequence, or

74
00:03:47.040 --> 00:03:48.040
you could think of it as impact.

75
00:03:48.040 --> 00:03:52.180
And when we have likelihood
multiplied by impact we get exposure.

76
00:03:52.180 --> 00:03:56.330
And exposure is what we see in red,
yellow, and green on the matrix here.

77
00:03:56.330 --> 00:04:00.787
And so something that is at
the lower left hand quadrant, lower,

78
00:04:00.787 --> 00:04:06.732
lower left hand on both, which will be
highly unlikely, and slightly harmful.

79
00:04:06.732 --> 00:04:11.130
At the the intersection of those two,
we see in green, an insignificant risk.

80
00:04:11.130 --> 00:04:14.820
Now you will see this ranking in this
set up done slightly differently,

81
00:04:14.820 --> 00:04:18.910
sometimes it's done with numbers,
sometimes it's done with categories.

82
00:04:18.910 --> 00:04:22.900
So you may see a one, two, three matrix
and one, two, three, one, two, three.

83
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:25.479
And you do a one and
one is one at the lower left, and

84
00:04:25.479 --> 00:04:29.640
a three times three at the upper right,
in red, for extreme, will be nine.

85
00:04:29.640 --> 00:04:32.650
And so you see this matrix done
differently, but ultimately,

86
00:04:32.650 --> 00:04:34.140
it represents the same thing.

87
00:04:34.140 --> 00:04:37.090
It's a probability, impact,
and exposure matrix, and

88
00:04:37.090 --> 00:04:40.460
we're talking about probability
is likelihood, by the way.

89
00:04:40.460 --> 00:04:43.650
Impact is going to be consequence, and

90
00:04:43.650 --> 00:04:46.540
exposure is ultimately the ranking,
right, that we get.

91
00:04:46.540 --> 00:04:50.520
And so you hear it often sometimes
referred to as a pie matrix or

92
00:04:50.520 --> 00:04:51.760
a pie chart.

93
00:04:51.760 --> 00:04:54.880
Not the pie chart you think of where
we're carving up the circle, but

94
00:04:54.880 --> 00:04:59.020
a risk management pie chart is
a probability impacted exposure table.

95
00:04:59.020 --> 00:05:02.864
And so it can be referred to that way,
sometimes done as likelihood consequence,

96
00:05:02.864 --> 00:05:04.290
doesn't really matter.

97
00:05:04.290 --> 00:05:07.880
The idea is that for the security
professional, we wanna be able to rank

98
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:12.690
our risks in the organization based on
the likelihood that they will occur.

99
00:05:12.690 --> 00:05:14.540
And the impact if they do occur.

100
00:05:14.540 --> 00:05:19.090
And obviously the higher the likelihood,
as we move up of the scale on the left and

101
00:05:19.090 --> 00:05:21.130
as we move over on the right.

102
00:05:21.130 --> 00:05:25.990
The more likely something is to happen and
the higher impact it has when it does.

103
00:05:25.990 --> 00:05:29.700
The more likely it is to occur and
the more impact it will have when it does

104
00:05:29.700 --> 00:05:34.090
occur, changes the rating from green
to yellow, from low to medium.

105
00:05:34.090 --> 00:05:37.480
Or insignificant to low to medium,
and from medium to high.

106
00:05:37.480 --> 00:05:40.730
To extreme at the upper right hand area or
quadrant and

107
00:05:40.730 --> 00:05:43.560
an extreme risk very likely to occur.

108
00:05:43.560 --> 00:05:47.000
High likelihood, extremely harmful
is one that we have to mitigate or

109
00:05:47.000 --> 00:05:48.440
address immediately.

110
00:05:48.440 --> 00:05:52.050
Because chances are it's gonna happen and
when it does it's gonna hurt us and

111
00:05:52.050 --> 00:05:53.750
it's gonna have a very negative impact.

112
00:05:53.750 --> 00:05:58.240
But one that is insignificant, highly
unlikely to occur even if it does occur,

113
00:05:58.240 --> 00:06:02.240
extremely unlikely to cause us
any significant harm or duress.

114
00:06:02.240 --> 00:06:04.810
Is one that we may get
around to at some point but

115
00:06:04.810 --> 00:06:08.310
even if we don't get around to it before
it happens, we might not even notice it.

116
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:10.210
And let alone if it does happen and
we do notice it,

117
00:06:10.210 --> 00:06:12.360
it's gonna be very inconsequential.

118
00:06:12.360 --> 00:06:16.000
So we wanna use a matrix like this
to understand how to rank risks and

119
00:06:16.000 --> 00:06:20.080
as a result, judge what our risk
profile or risk appetite may be.

120
00:06:20.080 --> 00:06:25.050
The higher value the target, the more
likely it is that it can be compromised,

121
00:06:25.050 --> 00:06:28.850
the more impact it will have,
the more high the risk ranking will be.

122
00:06:28.850 --> 00:06:31.580
And as a result, the less likely
we are to tolerate that risk.

123
00:06:31.580 --> 00:06:34.940
The risk appetite, in other words,
should be considered to be low for

124
00:06:34.940 --> 00:06:36.996
the risk profile of
the organization in this area.

125
00:06:36.996 --> 00:06:41.870
But we do wanna understand that
we will have a risk appetite or

126
00:06:41.870 --> 00:06:45.950
profile that is made up of a mixture
of low, medium and high risks, right?

127
00:06:45.950 --> 00:06:49.020
We're not just as, we were just
talking about right off-camera for

128
00:06:49.020 --> 00:06:52.865
one of our colleagues here, we're not
just gonna survive on soda by itself.

129
00:06:52.865 --> 00:06:54.920
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're not just gonna survive on healthy

130
00:06:54.920 --> 00:06:56.430
food by itself right?

131
00:06:56.430 --> 00:06:59.110
At least in theory most of us
don't since you said except for

132
00:06:59.110 --> 00:07:03.330
genetic abnormalities and
occasional strong constitutions right?

133
00:07:03.330 --> 00:07:04.930
The reality is that, yeah,

134
00:07:04.930 --> 00:07:07.130
we're gonna have a mixture
